INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator HILL (South Australia—Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL (South Australia—Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy, will be absent from question time today. Senator Parer will be delivering the keynote address to the annual conference of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association in Darwin. During his absence, I will take questions relating to the portfolios of primary industries and energy, and industry, science and tourism.

—My question is addressed to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. Senator, the Treasurer announced in writing that sales tax will be payable on all vehicles bought by state and local governments after 3.15 p.m. on 11 June. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer then announced orally on 14 June that the earlier announcement was wrong, and that only certain cars would be taxed. Could you please advise the Senate of any precedent of withdrawing a written taxation announcement with an oral one. Do you believe that this is a good way to make tax policy? Has any tax been charged to state or local governments under the previously announced regime, and will this tax be refunded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Wheelwright's question, I think he has got his starting point wrong. The fact is that on 11 June, in advance of the Premiers Conference, the Treasurer announced the Commonwealth's proposals in relation to the conference, including the question of sales tax. He said in that statement on 11 June that the Commonwealth would be proposing to remove the exemption from sales tax currently enjoyed by Commonwealth, state, territory and local governments. He also said, in terms of the specifics, that it would apply to vehicles purchased from that day by Commonwealth, state and territory governments. He also said that, so far as the remainder of the sales tax arrangements for non‐vehicles was concerned, that would involve negotiations with the states on transitional arrangements and the like.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the position that the Commonwealth government went into the Premiers Conference on. The reason why it went in on that basis was, of course, because it was aware—as were all the states, Senator Wheelwright, contrary, I think, to your party opposite, which vandalised the finances of this country for 13 years—that it was necessary for all members of the Australian community and all levels of government to make a contribution towards meeting the deficit reduction of $8 billion that the government inherited two days after the election.

Fortunately, the whole basis for the Premiers Conference was that—unlike Labor opposite—the state and territory premiers and leaders acknowledged that there was a need and a responsibility on all our parts to make a contribution to that deficit reduction which was the direct cause of the irresponsibility of the previous Labor government. As happens with all premiers conferences—and they have been the same from time immemorial—the whole basis of the conference is that you go and discuss the different ways of meeting the objectives.
The important outcome of the Premiers Conference was that the result—the bottom line result—was a very satisfactory outcome indeed for the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not for the taxpayer, Jim.

—Yes, because, with the contribution that has been made by the state and territory leaders, we have a very significant and very important contribution towards the deficit reduction that we inherited from the previous Labor government. It is the bottom line that is important.

ANSWER.PARA: It is correct to say that we would have preferred to have had a more equitable result on the sales tax arrangements as a whole, but the outcome, so far as private vehicles are concerned, is that, where they form part of the remuneration package of an employee, they will be covered, and that is a very desirable advance. You had 13 years to do something about this—13 years. You were not game to tackle any of the hard questions. We had a go at it. We negotiated well with the Commonwealth, the states and the territories, and we achieved a very satisfactory result. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I still think there is a great deal of room for clarification here. Could you please advise the Senate to what vehicles the new sales tax will apply, what will be the rate of tax and from when the changes will apply.
—The sales tax will apply to privately plated vehicles of employees of Commonwealth, state and local governments—
—When?

—As from 11 June 1996, where those vehicles are wholly or partly included in the remuneration package of the employee. That is quite clear. It has been clearly stated in the outcome of the conference. I am surprised that Senator Wheelwright has not read the official release because that is precisely what it says.

—On a similar theme, I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I refer to the outcomes following the recent Premiers Conference Loan Council meetings. Could you please explain whether you considered the outcomes were satisfactory. Could you also explain who should shoulder the blame for the reduction in the states' and territories' general assistance grants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question because it follows on very naturally and well from Senator Wheelwright's question to me. Let me start with the part about who should shoulder the blame.
—Every time the pressure's on you fold. Why did you fold, Jim? You gave in to the premiers.

—The blame for the need for the deficit reduction strategy that this government has put in train with great courage and great integrity lies wholly and solely with the previous Labor government and, very importantly, with the previous Minister for Finance who is now the Leader of the Opposition in this country, Mr Beazley.
—What happened to the courage last week, Jim?
—Jim, have a look behind you.
—It was during Mr Beazley's reign as finance minister of this country that the finances of the federal government slipped to such an extent that—
—Order! I cannot hear what is being said in answer. There are too many interjections on my left and they will have to cease if we are going to go on with question time.

—The finances slipped to such an extent that this government inherited an $8 billion deficit which, contrary to what you opposite may believe, actually does have the effect of increasing interest rates, actually does have the effect of increasing unemployment, actually does have the effect of reducing job creation and actually does have the effect of reducing economic growth and reducing the living standards of all Australians. This government was elected to repair that damage that 13 years of Labor mismanagement and fiscal vandalism had caused.

ANSWER.PARA: Unlike you Labor Party members opposite, the welcome fact is that the state and territory leaders accepted that need. They were prepared to accept and shoulder their responsibilities in the interests of all Australians. What is absolutely disgraceful is that the Labor Party opposition in this chamber, which caused the problem through the erosion of integrity in government financing, is not prepared to accept and share in the need for the restoration of fiscal responsibility and the integrity of the finances of this country.

The outcome of the conference was very satisfactory indeed, because the result is that the states are going to contribute approximately $1.5 billion to fix up the budget bottom line over the next two to three years. They have accepted that in a spirit of compromise and cooperation which does them great credit, and discredits those opposite. They acted with a high degree of responsibility, and the Commonwealth accepts and welcomes that.

Let me say again that Labor created the problem. The government that was elected on 2 March was elected to fix the problem. It is fixing it. I am delighted that it is doing it with the full cooperation of the states and territories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I remind him of a statement made by the now Treasurer, Mr Costello, to the National Press Club on 17 May 1995, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is not our agenda to introduce new taxes. It is not our agenda to bulk up the currently existing taxes.
Do you agree that an expansion of the wholesale sales tax to cover items that are currently exempt from that tax constitutes the breaking of this promise? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not too sure what the now Treasurer said on 17 May 1995, but I can well believe that that is what he did say because everything that he and this government have done since the election has been in accordance with that statement. For you to say that the proposals put to the premiers last week constitute any change to that is a total misunderstanding by you of the nature of the taxation system.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that on numerous occasions before the election and on equally numerous occasions since the election the Treasurer, the Prime Minister, myself and others have made it clear that in terms of getting the finances of this country right, on the revenue side, the question of exemptions and anomalies are matters that need to be looked at. That is precisely what was done last week. That does not constitute any increase in taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —So $1.2 billion is not a new tax?

—If you want to look at people who break their promises, what about looking at a government which in the months before the 1993 election said that it had legislated into l-a-w law the biggest tax cuts in Australia's history. Two days after the election they sat down and worked out how they were going to deliberately break those promises, which they knew they never had any intention of meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: They were a government which, two months after the election in 1993, increased sales tax across the board and introduced new taxes over a whole range of areas. They were broken promises. Everyone knows that that was the case. The fact is, Senator Sherry, that nothing that was said by the government last week in any way contravened the total commitment that we have given to the Australian people that we will not be introducing new taxes or increasing existing taxes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, how does your defence of the Treasurer and the government sit with what you told this chamber on 28 June last year when you said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the government has now added to the disaster of the wholesale sales tax system by expanding it to cover a number of items, which I have already mentioned, that are currently exempt from such tax. That does constitute the breaking of a seemingly very firm promise by the government before the election that there would be no new taxes.
What do you think about what you said on this issue last year?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry obviously cannot understand the fundamental difference between a range of tax increases which the previous government, his government, did in government and the very responsible approach of the present government to the whole question of anomalies and exemptions in the taxation system, of which the approach of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister last week was a very important example. I just come back to the fundamental point that I made at the outset: this government is totally committed to no new taxes and no increases in existing taxes. That was the situation; that is the situation; that will remain the situation.

—My question is addressed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw the minister's attention to the report released by UNICEF last week showing that Australia is one of only five industrialised nations to have more than 10 per cent of its children living in poverty. Justice Marcus Einfeld says the report revealed that Australia has much to be ashamed of. How will the government's policy program alleviate this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to the UNICEF report, The progress of nations , which ranked industrialised countries according to the proportion of children living in poverty. This report is an appalling indictment of the former Labor government's record.

ANSWER.PARA: We all remember Bob Hawke, the former Prime Minister, in 1987 saying, `No Australian child will live in poverty by 1990.' Yet with six further years of Labor, what happened? The position substantially deteriorated—so much so that this report, this independent, objective report, found that 14 per cent of children in this country are living in families with inadequate incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's your answer.
—I will tell you. How does this compare with other countries? It is worse than Ireland, worse than Israel, worse than the United Kingdom, worse than Italy, worse than West Germany, worse than France—
—So the first thing you do is remove migrants from the list.
—worse than the Netherlands—
—So you remove migrants from the list.

—much worse than the Scandinavian countries, Senator Schacht. This is your record. The record of this former Labor government was that the battlers suf fered and the children of the battlers suffered even more. This was one of the reasons why it was thrown out of office.

ANSWER.PARA: It is pleasing that Labor spokesmen are just starting to accept the reality. You would have noticed Gary Gray, the party secretary, when he was asked a few days ago why they lost government, saying it was because they failed to understand the needs of families. That is what it is. Families suffered under your policy. Under your policy the gap grew between rich and poor; the poor became poorer and the families suffered. More children ended up in poverty. This is what you would call the social wage.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what you, Senator Crowley, came in here and boasted about every day—the achievements of Labor in the social wage. The achievement of Labor was that the number of Australian children in poverty grew.

ANSWER.PARA: When Gary Gray was pressed even further as to what was the problem, he said, `It was arrogance.' How correct he was! The government was too arrogant and forgot the needs of its supporters; too interested in Mr Keating's so-called big picture to worry about the masses out there who were suffering. It is not surprising that they were suffering. There was mass unemployment. There is still three-quarters of a million Australians out of work. They gave us youth unemployment of 30 to 40 per cent out in the region. These are the young people of Australia who could not get jobs under Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Increase poverty—that's your answer.

—As I said, they showed us a growing gap between rich and poor, so much so that we started to have social commentators talking for the first time about the growth of an underclass in this country. This is the legacy of Labor; this is the legacy we inherited.

ANSWER.PARA: We have a better approach. It does require hard decisions. It does require us to cut back on public expenditure, which they were not prepared to do, in order that we can take pressure off interest rates, help small business to grow, provide jobs for Australians who are not in work and give some hope to those who are in work. Under Labor, not only did we have mass unemployment but the living standards of those in work fell.

We have a different approach. Our approach is to increase wealth so that all can benefit, increase productivity and put in place a regime whereby workers' wages can increase. What you did under the accord was to keep the interests of Australian people down. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, when the Treasurer offered the states $619 million new money if they would accept removal of the exemption on sales tax, wasn't he really offering the $619 million agreed at the previous Premiers Conference, and included in the forward estimates? I ask you: was the Victorian Treasurer, Mr Stockdale, right when he stated categorically that this was a broken Howard promise? Further, would you agree with the South Australian Premier when he said that this whole episode was `dishonest'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the outcome, which is the important thing—
—Try telling the truth, Jim.
—What about the question, Jim? Don't you know the answer?

—Do you want to hear the answer or not? The outcome of the Premiers Conference last week has been seen by the Commonwealth, the premiers and the territory leaders as highly satisfactory for all concerned. Unlike Labor opposite and unlike you, Senator Faulkner, whose ranks within the left are apparently now so divided that you have not a clue which way you are going on these matters even as a faction, let alone as a party for which you are supposed to be the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, the fact of the matter is that there was a very satisfactory outcome, a cooperative outcome, on the part of all the Commonwealth and state leaders.
—Do you agree with Mr Stockdale? Do you agree with Mr Brown?

—You are behind the times yet again, Senator Faulkner. You are talking about a situation that did not eventuate in the outcome of the Premiers Conference. So far as the particular comments by Mr Stockdale and the South Australian Premier are concerned, I do not agree that there were broken promises involved, for precisely the sorts of reasons that I have given in answer to the earlier question. That is an academic issue now because, after some very sensible—sure, it was pretty spirited and I am sure it was pretty heavy—negotiations between all parties, they arrived at a result which was a very satisfactory bottom line for the Commonwealth and an arrangement that was well accepted by all the premiers.

ANSWER.PARA: That is why the press communique at the end of the conference says that the Commonwealth, states and territories have agreed that the real per capita indexation arrangements for financial assistance grants will be extended to 1998-99. That is a very positive advance for the states. It is a very positive and satisfactory outcome for them. The statement also makes the point, the very welcome point that I have kept saying today, that the states and the territories will be making payments to the Commonwealth over each of the next three years. It also makes the very important statement, which has not been widely reported, that `the need for these payments to be made by the states and territories will be reviewed annually at future Premiers Conferences in the light of the Commonwealth's fiscal position'.

This is unlike what your party did in its 13 years of government. It came in and tried to hit the states on the head with a sledgehammer. It was not prepared to negotiate with the states. We were, and we achieved a very satisfactory outcome for all concerned. That ought to be a matter for welcoming and acknowledgment on your part, not the dismal response that you have given to an outcome that is very good for the future of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you indicated that you did not agree with Mr Stockdale's comments. I ask you: do you believe the Victorian Liberal Treasurer was lying when he described Mr Costello's offer as a broken Howard promise?

—Mr President, on behalf of the Treasurer of Victoria, I take great exception to that allegation that Senator Faulkner has made. I would ask you to ask him to withdraw such a slur against one of the greatest treasurers of any state that this nation has ever seen.
—There is no reason to withdraw. He was asking whether you thought he was a liar. He was not saying that he is a liar.

—Mr President, I defer to you, but I repeat the point that Alan Stockdale, the Treasurer of Victoria, is one of the greatest treasurers of any state in the history of this nation. He has done what we in government are doing, that is, trying to get the finances of a bankrupt Labor government back into balance. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, the Treasurer said gleefully last week that he was pursuing the elimination of tax rorts on behalf of Mr and Mrs Joe Average. There is a very interesting article in the Weekend Australian by Mike Steketee, titled `Where the real rorts are'. It details a wide range of expensive rorts, which we are all aware of. Two of them, the infrastructure borrowings tax concessions and the superannuation tax concessions, result in Mr and Mrs Joe Average underwriting, to the tune of billions of dollars, the incomes of the well above average. I ask you Minister: using the Joe Average argument, are these two tax concessions under active review as part of the budget process or are some rorts more equal than others?

—So far as the preamble, I guess, to Senator Kernot's question is concerned, yes it is a fact that one of the reasons for the proposals last week was to remove inequities and potential rorts in the system. The outcome so far as the sales tax arrangements for vehicles is concerned, when they are part of a remuneration package, has been met very successfully.

BREAK.PARA: So far as the second issue that you have raised is concerned, which relates to superannuation and the like, you were asking whether they are being actively pursued in the context of the preparation of the budget. You know full well, Senator Kernot, that I am not going to speculate one way or another on any issue that might be involved in the preparation of the forthcoming budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you are claiming credit for something like $100 million when in these other rorts we are talking about $15 billion to $20 billion. In a general policy sense, can you tell us that the Treasurer is at least giving the same priority to pursuing the rorts as he is to severely cutting expenditure which hurts Mr and Mrs Joe Average, the ones he is now passionately protesting on behalf of?

—When the Treasurer announced on 12 March the deficit reduction strategy once it had become known to us the size of the deficit problem we face, he said that `the coalition was, remains and always will remain opposed to blatant rorts of the tax system and where those rorts are found to exist we will take action to stop those rorts'. I cannot add any more in the context of the budget preparation to what I have said in my earlier answer, and I am sure you would not expect me to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In announcing his proposal to inflict $1.2 billion in new taxes on the states and local government the Treasurer accepted that these authorities might retaliate by imposing taxes and charges on the Commonwealth. It is, of course, inconceivable that the government would not have made prior to this extraordinary breach of faith with the states some estimates of the potential impact of such retaliatory taxes and charges on the Commonwealth's budget bottom line. Can the Treasurer's assistant confirm that such estimates were made? Can he inform us what those estimates were?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Faulkner and others from the opposite side, Senator Murphy, you are several days out of date. The fact is that you are talking about a hypothetical situation that is now totally academic because the outcome of the Premiers Conference was that the Commonwealth, states and territories have agreed that the real per capita indexation arrangements for the financial assistance grants are going to be extended for an additional year, a significant advance on the present situation. The states and territories have agreed to make payments to the Commonwealth of $619 million in 1996-97, $640 million in 1997‐98 and $300 million in 1998‐99.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has agreed on the other side that the need for these payments to be made will be reviewed annually at future premiers conferences in the light of the Commonwealth's fiscal position. So you are putting to me a totally hypothetical situation which does not exist and which has no relevance in the Australia of 17 June 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We can at least conclude, Minister, that your government took this decision in clear breach of your election commitments without having a clue as to what the net benefit or loss to the Commonwealth might be. So on that basis, Minister, can you at least try to inform us at some later date what the estimates might have been?

—I can only repeat for Senator Murphy what I said before. He is out of date. It is an academic question. The Treasurer said last week that he would expect and would be prepared to negotiate with the states and the territories if they so chose, if the sales tax arrangements had gone ahead, in terms of a quid pro quo. There was a clearly stated intent there on the part of the government. It was equally clear, I would have thought, from what the Treasurer said, that so far as the premiers were concerned he would have been prepared to look at that situation had the situation arisen and developed. The fact is you are out of date. The situation did not develop and we now have a totally different ball game.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. In the context of the government's greenhouse response strategy and the government's recent press release of 4 June on the international climate change negotiations, I ask: do you recognise that Australia is one of the highest per capita users of energy in the world and that our vulnerability to measures to reduce greenhouse emissions is due in part to our choices in encouraging energy intensive industries based on fossil fuels and through our support of coal as a domestic energy source and major export? Do you recognise that the cost of meeting any obligations under the convention will become more difficult and expensive if we continue to fail at promoting efficiency and conservation and that any effective policy must include emission targets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think it is accepted that we are comparatively high among industrialised nations. It does relate to our industrial base to some extent and our reliance upon coal and other carbon fuels.
—What about the choices?

—Actually, some of the choices are really quite relevant. One of the criticisms you would put to me, Senator Margetts, is in fact that the LPG plants producing from the north‐west coast are contributing to this whilst in fact they are producing fuel that substitutes for poor quality coal in Asia and thus in a global sense are contributing to a better outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: That is why this whole picture is a complex one. You do not get the best picture simply by looking at the circumstances of each individual state. If you want to be fair, you should look at the contribution of each individual state to the total international picture. We, as a nation, must look at our contribution to that, and if there are ways in which we can improve our performance in relation to emissions of greenhouse gases we should do so.

In that sense, I take the opportunity to acknowledge the very positive programs that a number of Australia's largest companies have now entered into to improve their record. In particular, companies such as BHP, Shell and ICI joined with us in Melbourne a couple of weeks ago to announce voluntary programs to improve their performance—programs that provide technology that, in many ways, will lead the world. So we continue to make positive contributions in that regard.

We would also make a positive contribution if you, Senator, supported the one‐third sale of Telstra and we were able to put in place the largest revegetation program in the history of this country. But the positive contributions that Australians can make, when it does not suit your political purposes, you disregard.

It is a complex picture. We are not prepared to go to Geneva and sell Australian industry down the tube but we are prepared to say that all Australians—big or small, corporate or individuals—should play their part in contributing to improving the situation overall with regard to the emission of greenhouse gases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his response. The minister mentioned the press release of 6 June in which some of Australia's companies said that they were taking up the greenhouse challenge. That was applauded as one of the government's major responses to the greenhouse effect. In fact, would the minister agree that those companies did not say they were going to reduce their greenhouse emissions; they were just saying they were not going to increase them as much as they might have? So this does not even include any reductions in greenhouse gas emissions.

QUESTION.PARA: Would the minister also comment on an answer to a question on notice received on 24 August that said, amongst other things, that Australia uses 215 gigajoules per capita per annum, compared with China's 24 and India's nine gigajoules per capita per annum. We are promoting coal sales and coal‐fired power use to these nations, including through our foreign aid programs. We are the largest coal exporter in the world. If we do not take these targets seriously, why should they? If they do not take the targets seriously, with 45 per cent of the global population, how will we ever put our hand up to say we are reducing greenhouse gas emissions? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator to give some credit where it is due. If you look at the record of BHP, you will see that, in spite of a substantial increase in output, the proportion of greenhouse gas per tonne of output is falling. That is the way we want Australian industry to proceed. We do not want it to cut back output and we do not want it to cut back coal exports.

ANSWER.PARA: You may not appreciate it, Senator, but we are in big trouble with our current account in this country. We are the largest coal exporter in the world and you are asking us to cease that coal export. The effect of that, in part, would be the substitution of good quality coal exported from Australia by poor quality coal produced in Asia. How will that improve the overall international picture in relation to the greenhouse effect? It will not improve it at all.

We accept that we all have to play our part and that we can do better. We commend those Australian companies and individuals who are making an extra effort and we are looking to extend that process.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short. Given that sales tax will apply to privately plated vehicles controlled by the federal government, can the minister inform the Senate: how many such vehicles will be affected; what revenue will be raised; will departments be supplemented as they were for fringe benefits tax; and what will be the administrative cost of removing this exemption?

—Senator Lundy, you have asked several questions. I am not aware of the actual number of vehicles, nor am I aware of the answers to some of the more detailed aspects of the question. So far as the revenue is concerned, my understanding is that the estimate of the revenue will be of the order of $80 million to $100 million. I will take the rest of the detailed components of the question on notice and come back to you.
—Further on the issue of the exemptions: Minister, can you guarantee that the exemptions administered by your department will continue to apply to TPI pensioners?

—Again, subject to confirmation, my understanding is that the answer would be no. We are talking about vehicles that are owned by the Commonwealth and which are involved as part of a remuneration package and wholly or partly privately used. If they are not wholly or partly privately used and if they are not part of a remuneration package, the new provisions do not apply.

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Did the minister hold discussions with 49 non‐government women's organisations last week and, if so, can she inform the Senate of the results of her round table discussions with that diverse range of women's groups on the issues of domestic violence, the portrayal of violence in the media, and the stand by the government on gun control?

—Yes, I did meet with 49 national women's organisations last week. One of the things that I found fascinating was that the women at that meeting—who, I suppose it would be fair to say, would represent the broad range of the political spectrum—volunteered without my suggestion that they wanted to put out a communique endorsing the government's position on three separate matters, all relating to violence. They were: firstly, the government's position on gun control; secondly, Senator Alston's measure for setting up a ministerial committee on the portrayal of violence in the media, the internet and things like that; and, thirdly, the government's commitment to putting in place a national summit on domestic violence.
—Not industrial relations.

—Those 49 women's organisations from all over Australia endorsed the work that the government was doing in those areas, not mouthing rhetoric but really acting on the concerns of the majority of women in Australia today.
—What about health issues and industrial relations. Care of the aged. People with disabilities. Indigenous women's problems.

—I can hear some of the sisterhood babbling in the background here. They do not like to hear that our side of politics has virtue in the eyes of Australian women. And why is that? Because, unlike the previous government, we are not getting by on rhetoric; we are getting by on action.

BREAK.PARA: The other thing that Senator Ellison would be interested in, I am sure, is that I discovered, when I was chairing that meeting, that it is the first time that people there could remember that a minister responsible for the status of women was prepared to spend the entire day with the women who are members of the round table set up by the previous government—the people opposite. The round table was set up for consultation, for listening to the women of Australia, and yet my predecessors in this role—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you listen to them on industrial relations?
—Order!

—My predecessors in this role were not prepared to stay and listen to those women. I chaired that meeting for the entire day. They found that quite remarkable. This government, in all its actions, is trying to demonstrate by action, not word, that it is committed to the concerns of Australian women.
—What about indigenous women's problems?
—Or health? Or disabilities?
—Order!

—I can hear more and more of this noise going on, and you, Mr President, choose not to tell them to be quiet. I will just have to keep on going above the noise. These women were concerned that, in the past, they had not been able to get their agenda items up for discussion, that people did not have a chance to be heard and that the single day—from 10 till four—went past with very little consultation that was meaningful and very little opportunity for networking between women's organisations. I proposed to these 49 organisations—
—How can they consult if they can't get here?
—Order! There are too many interjections on my left.
—They do not like to hear the truth. That is the problem, Mr President.

—I think it is an important point, Mr President. —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. I ask: Minister, are you aware that one of the legacies of the previous Labor government is that spent fuel nuclear reactor rods from the Lucas Heights nuclear facility in Sydney are shipped to Dounreay in Scotland for reprocessing and that the first shipment has already gone? Are you aware of an opinion poll showing that 85 per cent of the population of that area do not want our nuclear waste? Are you also aware that Dounreay has a documented history of accidents and mismanagement of nuclear waste and that the area around Dounreay has the second highest rate of childhood leukaemia in Britain—the only worse area being around Sellafield, the other reprocessing plant? Will the new coalition government commit to investigating domestic alternatives for dealing with these reactor rods or, even better, use other types of technologies, such as cyclotrons, so that we do not produce this material in the first place?

—I can imagine the sort of hiding we would get from the Democrats if we said we would apply a domestic alternative. I have been to Sellafield; I have not been to Dounreay. I must say that the local community of Sellafield strongly supported the industry. Furthermore, I would have thought that basically reprocessing spent fuel rods is a sensible policy—it reduces the amount of ultimate waste and it ensures the greatest amount of energy output for the fuel that was obtained in the first instance. Provided, obviously, that it is done safely and that it is done in accordance with the various international conventions and obligations, we have no objection to that process taking place.

—Minister, I ask whether you are prepared to meet with Lorraine Mann, who was flown out from Scotland to speak with you and others to express the concerns of the local people. They certainly do not want that processing going on in their backyard. They are aware of both the environmental risks and also the health risks. Are you also aware that we will be getting back low‐grade nuclear waste? What is Australia going to do with that? Finally, how much is all this going to cost? What was the cost of that first shipment that was sent over on 19 April? We already have the world's worst greenhouse policy; we are running very close to the world's worst nuclear waste policy as well.

—The implication in that supplementary question was that the Democrats would prefer high‐grade waste to low‐grade waste, and I cannot understand that. But I would be more than happy to meet with the visitor from Scotland if she would like to educate me further in some of these matters.

I have no intention of commenting on something that I have not seen. But in terms of some of the generalities of what you are raising, the fact is that Mr Tuckey along with all members of the coalition are absolutely united in their objective to get rid of the fiscal vandalism that has pervaded this nation as a result of the policies of Labor governments over the past 13 years. In that, as I say, we are all at one.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the coalition is concerned, in that and in other issues, we are absolutely united to get Australia back on the path of growth so that we can again have job creation in this country, so that we can get unemployment down, so that we can take the pressure off interest rates and so that we can have lower taxes in this country. We do not have to spend so much money on meeting the interest payment and the repayments on the debts of Labor governments, which have squandered the heritage of this country and have sold assets of this nation and then just blown them away in recurrent expenditure. That is why Ralph Willis, the former Treasurer, said so accurately and with such feeling and with such honesty just two or three weeks ago that Labor lost the trust of the Australian people. TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid the minister is as equally ill-informed about his own party matters as he is about Labor Party matters. The central thrust of the question was: Minister, do you agree with Mr Tuckey's contention that any transfer of funds from one government to another just means higher taxes and/or lower services for the particular government involved? Isn't that a result of your decision in relation to the states at the meeting the other day?

—The answer is no, I do not agree with that. If you want a good example of why I do not agree with it, just look at your 13 years of mismanagement, where you saw spending go up and taxes go up, and what happened at the end of the day? You wrecked an economy. You left almost a million people unemployed. You left us well below achieving the growth potential of this nation. All the facts of the history of the last few years, not only in Australia but around the world, completely deny the proposition that Senator Evans is putting.

—The fact is that the Democrats are to the left of Fidel Castro. That is a pretty big statement. Now, of course, you are not interested in anything other than opposing.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to taxation.

He was not up to the job of answering those questions. His performance was as bad as Mr Costello's performance last week.

Mr Costello's approach was characterised by smugness and arrogance the whole time. At least by the end of this hour of question time there was no smugness and arrogance about Senator Short. The smile had been wiped off Senator Short's face. What Mr Costello did single‐handedly was turn the Premiers Conference into high farce and plummet Commonwealth-state relations in this country to historically the lowest level they have ever been. It ended in an ignominious backdown by Mr Costello and the Commonwealth. It was a comprehensive and humiliating failure for Mr Costello and the coalition government, which had backed him to the hilt on these measures.

We have never before seen such a chorus of criticism of the Commonwealth government as we saw on this occasion. This whole episode has been a debacle of enormous proportions. We saw an undisciplined and arrogant government. We saw ineptitude, incompetence and dishonesty from this Liberal government. (Time expired).

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the height of arrogance for Australian Labor Party senators, particularly Senator Faulkner, to come in here and talk about what happened at the Premiers Conference and what is happening to Australia's fiscal consolidation. These people opposite, many of whom have sat around the cabinet table, reigned over Australia at a time when we saw taxes go through the roof after promising no new taxes in 1993. Our tax has gone up by an enormous amount.
—But that's history!

—Senator Sherry says, `But that's history.' Senator Sherry is right; it is history. It is part of Australia's economic history and it is from the lessons of history, particularly over the last 13 years, that we should all learn.
—Jim Short repudiates history.

—Senator Short knows history a lot better than you know or shall ever know, Senator Sherry. The lessons of history tell us that you cannot have a government, as we had under Mr Hawke and then Mr Keating, that continues to spends more money than it earns, continues to run up debt to the cost of future generations. It is not going to particularly matter to Paul Keating but it will matter to his children and all children in Australia. We have had under 13 years of Labor continuation of fiscal mismanagement which is mortgaging the future of future generations of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: There has been $68 billion worth of increased debt in the four years of the Keating government, which has ensured that all Australians pay a premium in interest rates. They pay much higher interest rates than our trading partners around the world. Accumulated deficits, pushing that debt up, mean that not only do we pay higher interest rates for our homes but also small business people pay a premium if they want to borrow a bit of extra money to expand operations or set up a new business or employ more people.

Let us look at what Senator Faulkner was talking about in his speech in favour of his motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Short. He referred to the Premiers Conference. Who was a backbencher when sensible moves were being made towards getting federal‐state relations and financial relations back on track? Mr Keating. Mr Hawke when he was Prime Minister and Mr Greiner when he was Premier of New South Wales tried to make some progress in the very important area of federal‐state financial relations. They tried to get cooperation between the states and federal government in relation to fiscal management back on a sensible path.

Mr Keating, then a backbencher, decided that for his own personal political future he would go and undermine that process of federal-state relations—the very good start that was made by former Prime Minister Bob Hawke and premiers such as Mr Greiner. Mr Keating did that. Mr Keating got Australia back to the good old centralism where the federal government says what goes and that is what happens.

What occurred last week? The federal government and the state governments, through Mr Howard, Mr Costello and the five state Liberal premiers and the one Labor state premier, sat around in this building and came to an agreement which did a couple of things. The most important thing it did was ensure that the states share the burden. That occurred against their wills of course, because no state wants to give up hundreds of millions of dollars of taxation. None of them are going to come to Canberra and say, `Mr Howard, Mr Costello: here is a blank cheque. We are going to hand over this money to help you fill in Beazley's black hole.' They did it against their wills entirely.

All of the states are having to recover from some sort of pain. The state of Victoria was having to recover from the Cain and Kirner disasters. The state of South Australia was having to recover from the disastrous Bannon years and the State Bank fiasco. The state of Western Australia was having to recover from the Burke, Dowding and Lawrence years. They have all had to cut their budgets and go through the pain of fiscal consolidation after Labor mismanagement. Of course, federally we have to find around $8 billion just to give us a chance at bringing our budget back to even again, back in the black, so that we are not mortgaging the futures of young Australians.

Last week's Premiers Conference was a great success, and not only for the federal and state governments, who agreed to share this burden of trying to restore economic sanity to Australia. More importantly, the big winners out of last week's compact between the state and federal governments are future generations—the young people around Australia who will be able to look forward to a sound economic future because state Liberal governments and the federal Liberal coalition sat down and reached a sensible agreement in relation to Australia's future fiscal management. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell gave us a rosy version of what happened last week from the federal Liberal Party's perspective. You would not have got the same perspective from the Liberal Party at state level. You would not have got the same perspective from independent media commentators. You would not have got the same perspective even from those who were barracking for Mr Costello—the dries and rationalists in Australian economics. You would not have got them to give last week a tick at all. They in fact now blame Mr Costello for sabotaging their idea of tax reform in Australia and are holding him accountable for that as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week the federal government was defeated. The federal government introduced an ill‐advised, unthought out, badly executed and universally resisted proposal which was then undone and ultimately came to be a failure. That is what happened last week. Every Australian knows it. There might be people in this chamber who pretend that it did not occur, but it did. Everyone saw it on television and most Australians calculated the effect of this ill‐advised move on taxation on their own hip pocket as well.

The honeymoon that this government has been enjoying for the last three months—the first 100 days—is over. The electorate now sees this government in the real light: putting up a proposal which, according to answers given in question time today, has not even been calculated in terms of the retaliatory measures that would have been taken against it by the states. So the federal government did not even know what would happen when they ventured forward with this proposal. It was, as I have said, ill‐advised, unthought out, badly executed and, in the end, universally resisted.

It also brought out the arrogance of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and his personality, which was put on public display as the bully boy. We had it described by, weirdly and unbelievably, Senator Short. He turned in one of the most inept performances by a spokesman for the Treasurer I have ever seen in this chamber in all of my time here. We had a direct commentary on the Victorian Treasurer's comment that what we had seen from Mr Costello was a broken Howard promise. That was the comment of a Victorian Liberal Treasurer about a federal Liberal Treasurer. We had the representative of that federal Liberal Treasurer saying that the Victorian Liberal Treasurer was one of the best treasurers we had seen in Australia. The circle was completed. Someone in this is telling a lie. Yet in this effort to try to back one another they reach into hypocrisy.

What is well known about this proposal is that it would never have worked. Had anyone sat down for five seconds and worked out what would have occurred once the proposal had been introduced, they would have known that. Indeed Mike Cable in a small article in the Australian on the weekend, points to the retaliatory action and spells it out. We all know what it would have been. He said that the states would have held on to their cars for longer periods, thus thwarting it. Or they would have switched to smaller, less expensive cars and gone overseas, out of Australia, and bought foreign cars from the Koreans or others, thus thwarting it. Or the states would have reduced their fleets, thus thwarting the proposal. Or any one of the above three options would have been introduced in some way, thus thwarting the proposal. Mr Costello could not work it out. Everyone else could, and the premiers were the first and quickest ones to do the arithmetic as to how they would have overcome this proposal.

The point that needs to be made here is that this was an exercise in holding to ransom the core industry for the Australian manufacturing sector. This was Russian roulette with the Australian car industry. At a time when tariffs are falling, when the Australian dollar is appreciating, when government programs are being cut and when the industry is facing its greatest challenge, the Costello plan would have destroyed the car industry in Australia. There is no doubt. Ask Ford, Holden, Mitsubishi or Toyota. Four thousand jobs would have been directly lost. With a multiplier of 2½ to three, up to 12,000 jobs in the whole industry would have been lost.

—That's the multiplier. Don't you know that? The core of the Australian manufacturing sector would have been destroyed when we have a current account deficit which the manufacturing sector is turning back by growing its exports. This is a key export sector for Australia. Adelaide would have been turned into a rust heap. (Time expired)

I will emphasise that point again. It states `without new taxes and increased taxes'. The current government is only 3½ months into its term. Senator Kemp knows the truth of this matter. Time and again, you reiterated before the last election that there would be no new taxes and no extension of existing taxes.
Today we reminded Senator Short of Mr Costello's promise, which was this:
It is not our agenda to introduce new taxes. It is not our agenda to bulk up the currently existing taxes.

That was said time and again by the Liberal Party. I will be interested to see whether Senator Watson believes a sales tax extension of $1.2 billion is considered a new tax or an extension of an existing tax. We confronted Senator Short with his own words in this chamber on 28 June last year, which were these:

. . . the government has now added to the disaster of the wholesale sales tax system by expanding it to cover a number of items, which I have already mentioned, that are currently exempt from such tax. That does constitute the breaking of a seemingly very firm promise by the government before the election that there would be no new taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of my colleague the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), who successfully deflected a number of spurious opposition questions during question time this afternoon. My comments will have a very familiar ring to many colleagues sitting on the opposition benches who have come from the union movement. As many a good union organiser well knows, some of the most robust of negotiations result in the best outcomes. It was the outcomes on which my colleague Senator Short concentrated most successfully this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: A successful outcome followed the Premiers Conference. As Senator Short said, the outcome was satisfactory in that the states did recognise that they do have a role in overcoming a most embarrassing deficit that must be sheeted home to the previous ALP federal government. It makes for very easy government to run up debt. Some of this debt is deliberate while other debt results from bad policies. In this latter category, we categorise international debt, which rose from about $34 billion when those opposite came into power under the Hawke administration to about $180 billion when Mr Keating left office. The first responsibility of this responsible new coalition government is to restore the underlying budget. I believe that we are moving in that direction very satisfactorily.

Today's question time showed the utter hypocrisy of the ALP in relation to so-called broken tax promises. Other questions were preoccupied with attempting to debate or highlight a whole lot of immediate situations rather than concentrating on the final outcome. Perhaps those opposite were somewhat embarrassed as a result of what was a very satisfactory final Premiers Conference outcome, despite some hard bargaining in the process. I therefore take my hat off to all those state premiers who showed cooperation and leadership in aiming to overcome Labor's legacy of debt. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to Senator Watson who, in his usual way, has given a very lucid explanation of what the government is about. Senator Watson talked about outcomes as distinct from the means and mechanisms by which we get to the outcomes. The significance of the questions today and of looking at the means and machinery we use to get to the point that we want to is that it indicates the genuineness of what the outcomes ought to be as distinct from what they will be.

SPEECH.PARA: What happens with the $8 billion black hole, as it is called, is this: in spite of different economic messages coming through, the argument from the government is always that that $8 billion is fixed. How can it be fixed if the machinery by which it is ascertained shifts? The fact is that the machinery has shifted. The various elements that we look at to see whether there is an $8 billion deficit shift. Even though the shifts occur, become quite dramatic and are underlined by the premiers, it is never conceded by the government that the $8 billion is in question. The fixation on the $8 billion, in light of the fact that the means by which that is reached shift the whole time, brings us to the point that was brought out here today, which is that this side has a justifiable concern about the fact that the government will not concede that its $8 billion is not a fixed figure, even though the machinery by which that is ascertained shifts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
