TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the tragic loss of life of 18 soldiers who died on 12 June 1996 in service to their nation and conveys its heartfelt sympathy to the families, friends and communities in Townsville and Perth who mourn their passing together with all Australians.

This is a sad occasion. It seems to me that the least that we, the representatives of the people in this place, can do is to acknowledge the loss of these men in preparing for potential service in the interests of their country and to express our heartfelt sympathy to their families in particular who mourn their loss.

After long periods of peace the community sometimes takes for granted the role and the commitment of our service men and women and the fact that they are prepared to put their lives on the line in protection of us and our interests and that, in order that they can do so professionally and to the highest standards, they are prepared to take very major risks in reaching that level of training. Just occasionally—it happened in this tragic circumstance, but it has happened before and we could have equally passed motions such as this on previous occasions—they do pay for it with their lives and on other occasions they are very severely injured. It is important that we recognise that the work that they do for us is dangerous and recognise the sacrifice that they are prepared to make.

Specifically on this occasion we also need to recognise the sacrifice that families are prepared to make in allowing their men and women to enter the services and provide that safeguard for all of us. I know that they know the risks; there is no doubt about that. They know that what they do is dangerous. Their families know that it is dangerous. But that does not in any way excuse the horror of an event such as this when we have, in this instance, young men—it could just as easily have been women—at the height of their training and their professional career losing their lives in such tragic circumstances.

I have moved this motion in order to allow honourable senators to add a word or two to the sentiments that I have expressed and to join with me and others in expressing sympathy upon these deaths and in remembering particularly the families and friends who are grieving at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion and associate the opposition with the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill). This training accident occurred just before 7.00 p.m. on Wednesday of last week at the high range training ground north-west of Townsville when two Black Hawk helicopters collided. One Black Hawk lost its rotor blades and crashed, killing 12 of the 13 on board. The second Black Hawk lost its tail, but the crew was able to ensure that it landed belly first and nine of the 15 aboard survived.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifteen members of the Special Air Service based in Perth lost their lives and three members of the 5th Aviation Regiment based in Townsville lost their lives. The 10 who survived all sustained injuries. I think we should record the fact that the personnel at the scene of this horrific accident risked their own lives rescuing survivors as ammunition exploded at the crash site.

As is characteristic in a dangerous night training operation with soldiers who are at the peak of their training and in peak physical condition, the men were very young. They were between 24 and 35 years of age. The soldiers came from across Australia. The majority—eight—were from Western Australia but there were four Queenslanders, three from New South Wales, two Victorians and a New Zealander.

For all of us it brings home the dangers that are inherent in this sort of training. It is one of the most serious and tragic peacetime defence accidents and the greatest loss of life since the Voyager disaster.

BREAK.PARA: SAS training has to be very realistic. When I was the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel I had the opportunity to visit both Swanbourne and the 5th Aviation Regiment at Townsville. I had an opportunity to see at first hand the enormous dedication that is required by those who serve in these capacities in the Australian Army.

This was a very tragic accident. On behalf of the opposition, our deepest sympathy goes to the family and friends of those who lost their lives and, of course, to the Australian Army and the whole of the Australian Defence Force on what was truly an enormous loss.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to associate members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill. Today many of us offered our prayers at a cathedral service for the families of the 15 Special Air Service soldiers and the three soldiers from the Townsville based 5th Aviation Regiment who were killed in the Black Hawk helicopter collision last week.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragic accident last Wednesday night was the worst peacetime military accident since the sinking of the Voyager 32 years ago. It has shocked and saddened the nation. Those 18 young men were all in their 20s or early 30s—at the absolute peak of their lives. They were an elite force, highly skilled and trained at peak battle readiness, and constituted the absolute sharp end of the Australian Defence Force. Their loss to the 500 strong SAS regiment, the 5th Aviation Regiment, the Defence Force as a whole and the Australian nation is immeasurable. Many leave behind young families as well as parents, and my heart goes out to all relatives in this time of their mourning.

This tragedy is a harrowing reminder of the risk taken by members of the Australian Defence Force when engaging in military exercises in the course of their day-to-day working lives. I have a son-in-law in the infantry and am the grandfather of a young three-year-old, the son of an army family. It especially concerned me when my thoughts went to those young children who will not have the influence of their fathers around them for the rest of their lives.

We heard this morning at the very moving state memorial service at St Christopher's Cathedral that Australia had lost 18 dedicated citizens—18 men who were prepared to make a supreme sacrifice for the good of our nation. These men paid the ultimate price in serving their country. Australia owes them and every member of the Defence Force a great debt of gratitude for their role in securing and defending this country. On behalf of the National Party in the Senate, I extend my deepest condolences and prayers to the bereaved and to the 10 soldiers injured and their families and friends in this time of mourning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would also like to be associated with the condolence motion before the Senate today. On behalf of the Democrats, I extend my deepest sympathy to the families and friends of the 18 members of the Special Air Service Regiment and the 5th Aviation Regiment who lost their lives in the collision of two army Black Hawk helicopters near Townsville last Wednesday night. This has been a great loss, clearly, for the wives, families and relatives of these men. But it is a loss not only for them; it is a loss also for the Australian nation and for the Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish all those who were injured in this tragic accident a full and speedy recovery. In some ways, the memories that they retain and the fact that they survived will be something that they themselves will deal with in the coming years. Of course, incidents such as this underline the risks members of our Defence Force face even in peacetime. The training that they do is not mickey mouse but highly realistic and, as this accident showed, one which involves a high degree of risk. Yet the men and women who serve in the defence forces know the risks associated with their work. To their great credit, they willingly accept these risks in order to protect and defend their country.

I believe we all owe a debt of gratitude to all the brave men and women who choose to serve their country in this way. We also owe a debt of gratitude to these fine young men who gave their lives or who were injured in service to their country last week.

On behalf of the Democrats, I offer my condolences and support to all those who have been touched by this tragic event and add my prayers to those that have been offered. I also commend all of those who assisted in rescuing and treating the injured for the courage and skill they exhibited under what were the most extreme circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Greens (WA), I wish to be associated with the condolence motion that the government has put today for the 18 service personnel who lost their lives in a training operation to the north-west of Townsville. As has been mentioned, three of the personnel were from the 5th Aviation Regiment in Townsville and 15 were from the Special Air Service Regiment based in Western Australia. The role of the Special Air Service division is in such things as counter‐terrorism and insurgence training here and elsewhere. The Greens (WA) wish to join with others in expressing our sadness to the relatives and friends of the personnel, and we wish a speedy recovery to those people who have been injured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to be associated with Senator Hill's condolence motion. Wednesday, 12 June this year was a very sad day for all Australians when the worst peacetime military aviation disaster occurred, snatching the lives of 18 young Australians who were prepared to sacrifice their lives for the rest of us. It seems so insignificant to express one's sympathy to the wives, the girlfriends, the children, the parents, the brothers, the sisters and the wider family and friends at a time when such wonderful lives have gone from people who were prepared to put everything on the line for the rest of us.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be said that our pride in what men such as the ones who lost their lives do is enduring. As a Western Australian senator, it grieves me to say that eight of those 18 personnel came from Western Australia. They were Captain Timothy James Stevens, Sergeant Hugh William Ellis, Corporal Andrew Constantindis, Corporal Brett Stephen Tombs, Lance Corporal Darren Robert Oldham, Trooper Timothy John McDonald, Trooper Michael John Bird and Signaller Hendrick Peeters. That is not to diminish the importance of those others who gave their lives, but to those from Western Australia I would like to pay significant tribute.

I would also like to acknowledge and thank all of those service personnel and civilians who helped with the rescue and who will no doubt continue to help the survivors and the relatives of both the deceased and the survivors. I extend my very good wishes to those men who did survive the tragedy, particularly those who, once again, came from my state of Western Australia: Corporal Dominic Boyle, Corporal Gary John Proctor, Trooper Gerard Crossley Bampton and Trooper Glenn Robert Sutton. Those people will no doubt come home to our fine state and continue the work that they are yet to finish. I certainly acknowledge all of those who have been so tragically affected. I trust that all those fine men will rest in peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones, Sen Gerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse the remarks of previous speakers and to support the motion of condolence by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), which is supported by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). It was certainly a sad day for Queensland, for Australia and for all Australians when this tragedy took place involving two Black Hawk helicopters. It is with great sadness that one speaks today about the tragedy. The accident caused the untimely death of 18 of Australia's great servicemen: 15 were from the SAS and three were air service people and crew. Ten people were injured.

SPEECH.PARA: To those families who have suffered the loss—to the wives, mothers, fathers, sons, daughters, friends and relatives—I extend my sympathy. I believe that no words can make up for the loss that they have suffered.

Out of the accident came some incredible acts of courage—mates saving mates. I believe that needs to be mentioned today. The description by Captain David Burke, a surviving helicopter pilot, of those acts of courage shows clearly the mateship, the training and the way in which soldier helped soldier. Captain Burke said that staff stationed on the ground raced into action as the helicopters hit the deck. He said:
. . . they had medics there . . . they were pulling people out, there were people going into the flames of the aircraft to pull them out.
Captain Burke went on to say:
We are very lucky to be here. We did not think that we were going to be, but the training we received here in the army aviation is the best in the world.

Captain Burke said that he would be happy to fly again and rejected suggestions that the helicopters were below par. That is something that the inquiry will have to look into, but it is not something that I wish to comment on today. He went on to say:
It is built to survive those sorts of impacts and I just got out and walked away. That is only because it was such a magnificent aircraft.
Obviously, we are all very upset. It is a risk you take in this sort of operation. When it happens, it really affects us all.
I think that that sums up how everyone feels, not only the army but also all senators in this chamber and people throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 June this year, 18 men tragically lost their lives in the course of serving their country. As we have heard today, 15 of those 18 men were from the Special Air Service and three from the 5th Aviation Regiment. On that night of the tragedy, the exercise involved an anti-terrorist exercise. It has been described as high risk, but for these men it was routine. I rise to pay tribute to these men, to the sacrifice that they and their families have made for their country and to the important role those serving in the armed forces play in peace time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Special Air Service, famous for its operations in Borneo in the mid‐1960s and in south Vietnam from 1966 to 1971, was firstly set up as the SAS company in Swanbourne, Western Australia, on 25 July 1957. At that stage, it consisted of four platoons, comprising 200 soldiers.

On 4 September 1964, the company was expanded to regimental strength and was renamed the Special Air Service Regiment. The Special Air Service Regiment gained much praise for its work in Vietnam in the late 1960s and early 1970s, with patrols alerting the Australian task force in Vietnam to heavy enemy build-up east of Nui Dat in August 1966. This was immediately before the battle of Long Tan, which was to be Australia's biggest battle in the course of that conflict.

The Special Air Service's mission is to conduct special operations to promote the security of Australia and protect its people and its interests. To that end, we all owe a great deal to those 18 men and their defence force counterparts around the country.

Newspaper reports since last week's tragedy have told of extreme acts of bravery, including a crewman dying while running through flames and exploding ammunition to drag an injured soldier from the burning aircraft. Witnesses reported rounds going off, ammunition flying in the air and explosives going off in the rear of aircraft at the same time as SAS personnel and aircrew were going into the flames, cutting people free and taking them out of the exploding helicopters.

The West Australian on the morning after the tragedy reported that the Special Air Service is the Australian Army's elite, a close group which regards itself as family. The bravery shown last Wednesday has highlighted that closeness.

For my own part, I understand that the use of live ammunition is necessary during training, which must be dangerous if it is to be effective. The Special Air Services motto `Who dares wins' is an apt reflection of the regiment's understanding of the dangers associated with its duties. I ask the Senate this evening to remember the families of those who have died and to remember those who were injured and are recovering in hospital. I wish them all a speedy recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other senators in expressing my condolences to the families and friends of those victims of the Black Hawk helicopter crash on the high range country near Townsville last week. Australia has an extraordinary and proud military history that recognises the sacrifices that both soldiers and civilians make during wartime.

SPEECH.PARA: The great majority of Australians have not experienced wartime, which we can only be very thankful for, but last week the whole nation witnessed a tragedy that was a stark reminder of the dangers that face our defence forces all the time. It was a tragedy that ran a shiver down everybody's spine. Our defence forces face danger on a day-to-day basis. It may not be danger in the expected form of war or armed conflict but it is still present when Australia's armed forces are part of peacekeeping or training for all eventualities and, in particular, anti-terrorist activities.

Fifteen fit, young men who served in Australia's most elite force, the Special Air Services regiment, lost their lives last Wednesday afternoon. As a part of that service, they were practising anti-terrorist manoeuvres when their Black Hawk helicopters collided and crashed. In addition, three pilots and air crew from the 5th Aviation Regiment died. As a result, these men paid the ultimate price in their desire to defend their country. The SAS acknowledge they are in a high risk business and they suffer at least one fatality in training per year, which is probably something that not a lot of Australians realise. I speak today to honour these men and their families for the sacrifice they have made and the terrible sorrow and sense of loss families and friends are feeling at this moment. Nothing we can say can make them feel any joy at this time.

Recently I had the opportunity to officially dedicate a peace tree in Coonamble in western New South Wales to those locals who had made sacrifices both at home and abroad during World War II. Many locals turned up for the ceremony to make sure that those sacrifices made during the world war were not forgotten. So too the sacrifices of these young men will not be forgotten.

There will also be many, especially within the defence forces, who will be affected personally by this tragedy. In Singleton, New South Wales, where my electorate office is located, there is the Singleton army camp where at least eight of these men went through the infantry school. Tomorrow they will hold a memorial service, and I am very sorry that I am not able to be there to help them commemorate this loss.

Northern New South Wales will particularly mourn the loss of Brett Tombs, who was among the casualties. Brett Tombs' parents live in Armidale and he had plans to resign from the SAS to continue his university studies at the Armidale university.

We must not forget that, as well as being fine soldiers, these men were also sons, husbands and fathers who had a role outside their service involvement. Those victims as well will feel this loss for the rest of their lives. The grief of the relatives and friends of these soldiers can only be understood by other people who have lost loved ones in the defence forces.

These servicemen will be added to the list of servicemen and women who have given their lives for the defence of Australia. There is no doubt that this loss will also be felt throughout Australia. I am sure that I speak on behalf of all senators when I say that we are also extremely saddened by the loss of these fine young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to associate myself with the motion moved by Senator Hill expressing deep regret at the tragic loss of life of 18 soldiers in the defence helicopter tragedy. I wish to extend my personal sympathy and condolences to the families and friends of those who died; those who were injured; and in fact to the whole of the service's family, who are all deeply shocked by the tragedy which will continue to impact on them for many years to come.

PARA.BREAK: It is a tragedy that has been felt throughout Western Australia because the SAS enjoys a special place within Western Australian society. I think every Western Australian either knows someone in, or has had some association with, the regiment. They have a fine reputation not only as soldiers but also as citizens in Western Australia. I have had a great deal of contact mainly with former personnel who have often gone on to serve in other services of the community, such as the fire and ambulance services, when they leave the SAS. As I have said, the SAS and its per sonnel have a very high reputation throughout the Western Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: On a lighter note, my main contact with serving members has been on the rugby field where I have learnt of their strength, hardness and endurance while generally being knocked about by them. It has always been a great pleasure to play against a local rugby club called Associates, which over many years has had a close association with the SAS and many SAS soldiers have played for and represented the club. I express my sympathies to the club and its members because I know they feel the loss very deeply.

I wish to add my sympathies to those expressed by other senators. We have had a particularly tragic couple of months, this following on the Port Arthur tragedy. It is to be hoped that no such similar event occurs again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to join with other senators in supporting the motion moved by Senator Hill today. I will just make one or two observations. Virtually everything that needs to be said has been said with regard to this motion. I associate myself with it in acknowledging the passing of the 18 men, eight of whom were Western Australians, in the preparation and training for service to their country.

SPEECH.PARA: Arguably, the SAS is the most elite of all the various services that engage in this type of training and activity, and that has been acknowledged in many areas. My association directly with the SAS, unlike Senator Evans's, has been on the cricket field, not on the football field. Once again, I can say that on the cricket field they are very well trained, extremely fit and worthy opponents.

In addition to what has already been said, I particularly want to acknowledge the speed with which details of those involved in this unfortunate tragedy were released to friends and loved ones. I want to acknowledge the speed with which the Department of Defence responded to my contact and to commend the manner in which it handled the situation. As well as the next of kin and close loved ones—wives, girlfriends and children—there is a ring of friends associated with those involved in this tragedy. I was in outback Western Australia at the end of last week and I know there were people out there wondering who had been involved and what had occurred. It is important to acknowledge the quick response of the department to their request for details.

I also offer my prayers and sympathy to the families involved. I acknowledge the courage of those who took part in the rescue mission. Their actions highlighted what people can do in the depths of adversity when called upon to act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the wife and mother of former soldiers and I can therefore identify very much with how the families of those involved in the Black Hawk tragedy are coping today. Having also been a shadow minister for defence, I visited both the SAS and the aviation regiments on a number of occasions over the last eight or nine years.

SPEECH.PARA: The SAS Regiment and the 5th Aviation Regiment in Townsville have a very special feeling about them. There is great esprit de corp, a great sense of being a regimental family in which everybody is bound up in the one endeavour, not just the Defence Force personnel but also those who love and support them. I can imagine just a little of what it must be like in Perth and in Townsville for those units, the survivors, their loved ones and the loved ones of the victims in trying to come to terms with this terrible tragedy.

The members of these two regiments have great pride in their achievements. They have great skills, and great commitment to the role they have been given to play in the defence of Australia. Just last year I was in Perth when some of those who are now dead demonstrated to me their skills and training, so I feel this loss very personally.

We should all be very proud of these men. They have a training regime which is constant and unremitting. The level of skill they achieve, as we have read and heard about in the last few days in connection with the rescue of the survivors, is what tells when times are tough. Training will out; you get to the stage where training takes over and, in a sense, thought processes are suspended.

I do not want to go on and on but these men are not usually very newsworthy. It saddens me that, while in the last few days the newspapers and other media have focused on the role of our army, we usually ignore the role it plays altogether. I do not want to strike a sour note now but I ask Australians: do Defence Force personnel have to die before the nation publicly expresses its pride in their commitment and skills. They serve us every day in peacetime and they train hard to ensure that we stay at peace. I hope that one thing Australians will learn from this tragedy is that we all must let our defence force know how much we value them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —The nation has suffered a very grievous loss: the loss to the army of 18 soldiers; the loss, the greatest in its history, to the Australian Special Air Service Regiment of 15 of its members, all from one squadron—roughly 15 per cent of a squadron, which is a huge casualty rate for any unit to bear. But above all, there is the irreparable loss to these men's families. These men were not 18‐year‐olds; they were mostly 10 years older than that. So the loss was not only to their parents: it was to their wives and children. I am told that at least two of those who were killed had three very young children. Our deepest sympathy goes out to those families at this moment. Nothing we can do can restore their fathers and their husbands.

SPEECH.PARA: I found the size of the loss very hard to comprehend. You can understand two or three people being killed but the enormity of 18 being killed in one accident is almost beyond comprehension. It was only on Friday morning when I was standing in the rain at the memorial service held outside the brigade headquarters in Townsville and saw the 18 rifles with bayonets attached stuck into the ground with the sand berets of the SAS and the blue berets of the 5th Aviation Regiment on the butts that the size of the loss came through to me. It graphically illustrated the nature of military service.

Those who have never worn the uniform of the armed services often do not appreciate what is involved. The Australian Defence Force is not a collection of civil servants in uniform. It does not exist to provide ceremonial parades or United Nations peacekeeping duties. The task of its members is to defend the nation with their lives when all else fails. Because of that, the training must be as realistic as possible, and it must always, therefore, be dangerous. Despite the best of planning, some accidents will always occur, though we and the services themselves must do everything to prevent and forestall lives being lost.

Wednesday night's accident does illustrate the risks involved in this training, the selflessness of the Australian Defence Force and the readiness of its members to train themselves for the roles they will need in war. We affirm our gratitude for their selflessness and our pride in their achievements, and we mourn their passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the quite moving speeches that have been given so far, and which I endorse, it seems to me that what I ought to say is this: that the quality of the sacrifice made by our fighting men on this occasion is the same as that which would have attached to the sacrifice they would have made had they fallen fighting in a war defending Australia. The quality of the sacrifice is the same whether they gave their lives in battle for their country or in the preparation for such a battle. The same thing can be said about the quality of the sacrifice made by their family and friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 1 June 1996 of former senator Thomas Joseph Tehan, a senator for the state of Victoria from 1975 to 1978.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Saturday, 1 June 1996, of Thomas Joseph Tehan, a senator for the state of Victoria from 1975 to 1978, places on record its appreciation of his meritorious parliamentary service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Thomas Tehan was born in Kyabram, Victoria, on 18 January 1916. He started his education at the Timmering East State School and St Mary's Convent, Tatura, completing his secondary education at Xavier College, Kew. He began working in the state taxation office, and in 1942 he was awarded a university free place which enabled him to successfully go on and complete a law degree at Melbourne University.

He joined the Victorian Crown Solicitor's Office in 1943. In 1947 he was admitted to practice as a barrister and solicitor of the Supreme Court of Victoria, and it was also at this time that he began his long association with Morrison and Sawers Solicitors in Kyabram, where he worked as a former partner and consultant until his death.

Tom joined the then Country Party in 1949 and held positions of member of the Central Council from 1965 to 1973, senior vice‐president from 1973 to 1975 and Victorian state president in 1975. Last year he was awarded life membership of the National Party.

Tom was elected to the Senate in 1975. In his maiden speech on 26 February the following year he spoke of his support and commitment to primary industry issues and discussed the problems that faced Australian primary producers, in particular the fruit industry. He highlighted the importance of the family as a basic unit of society, and acknowledged the benefits of social welfare programs such as the child endowment scheme. He also expressed concern about the high level of road related deaths among young Australians, telling of his close association with a pilot scheme designed to educate young drivers at the newly established Goulburn Valley driver training complex in Shepparton.

Tom made many contributions during his term in the Senate. Of particular note was his committee work. He worked as a member of the Senate Publications Committee, the Standing Committee on Social Welfare and the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, as well as estimates committees and the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System. He also served as chairman of the Joint Government Parties Law and Government Committee, helping argue the case for constitutional amendments, including the vital question of filling casual Senate vacancies with people of the same party, put to the 1977 referendum.

When Tom completed his term in the Senate in 1978, the then Liberal leader Reg Withers praised the `fundamental commonsense' that Tom brought to this chamber and commended him on his service to his town. It is interesting that he returned and continued to work for the local community. He served the Chamber of Commerce, the District Memorial Hospital Board and Rotary, and he was made a life member of the Knights of the Southern Cross.

Tom's years of dedication and service to his local community were recognised in 1993 when he was named as the Kyabram Citizen of the Year. He led an active and rewarding life that was committed to helping others. He will be fondly remembered and sadly missed by those who knew him. On behalf of the government, I extend to his wife, Nance, son, Terry, and daughters, Maree, Ann and Maureen, our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party in the Senate, I rise to support the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill on behalf of the government for Tom Tehan, a former National Party senator for Victoria. I understand that some of Mr Tehan's family are present here today. I welcome them and wish to extend my greatest sympathy for the passing away of Mr Tehan.

SPEECH.PARA: Tom Tehan made an enormous contribution to the community of Kyabram and also to the Victorian National Party through his decades of public and community service. At his funeral last week, the whole town of Kyabram came to a halt. Shops and businesses closed as thousands of people packed the St Augustine's church and lined the streets in demonstration of their respect, gratitude and sorrow at the passing of this great community leader.

Tom Tehan epitomised the National Party. He made a huge contribution to the community with his years of community service at the grassroots level. He took the concerns of the organisations and of the people with him when he entered the Senate in 1975.

Tom Tehan was born in Kyabram, Victoria on 18 June 1916. He was educated at St Mary's Convent, Tatura, and Xavier College. In 1945, he obtained a Bachelor of Laws from Melbourne University. Upon graduation, he obtained employment in the state taxation office and then proceeded to the Victorian Crown Solicitor's Office. In 1947, he was admitted as a barrister and a solicitor in the Supreme Court of Victoria and, two years later, joined the firm of Morrison and Sawers. It was at this time he joined the Country Party—later the National Country Party and now the National Party—and his lifelong association with the party began.

Tom Tehan was a man of unflagging commitment and drive. Despite the demands of a challenging legal career, assisting his wife Nance with his family responsibilities for his four children, and his active involvement in parish life, he still found time and commitment to contribute to the community of Kyabram. He was a board member of Kyabram hospital from 1948, served as president for 10 years from 1963, and was made a life governor in 1985.

He gave three decades of service to Rotary, during which time he was president of the Kyabram club in 1963-64 and district governor from 1980-81. He also served as a trustee of the Elderly Citizens Committee, the Kyabram Youth Club and the Kyabram Chamber of Commerce, among many others. For this long and meritorious service to the community, Tom was named Kyabram Citizen of the Year in 1993. He was made a member of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta in recognition of his community and charitable works.

The Country Party greatly welcomed the drive of Tom Tehan and called on his natural leadership qualities. He became state vice‐president in 1973 and state president in 1975. He was a confidant of Jack McEwen and was a person everyone in the Victorian National Party turned to for guidance and advice.

In 1975, Tom Tehan entered federal parliament as part of the Fraser‐Anthony landslide victory. In his first speech in the Senate, he foreshadowed the areas he would endeavour to represent: primary industry in particular, the dairy and horticultural industries, and family and youth issues. He threw himself wholeheartedly into committee work. His legal expertise was called on to chair the Joint Government Parties Law and Government Committee, and he was a hardworking member of the legal and constitutional affairs committee, the social welfare committee, the publications committee, and the Select Committee on Drug Trafficking and Drug Abuse.

A man of immense promise, talent and drive, it was a great loss to the parliament and his Victorian constituents that his contribution was limited to only one term. Everyone spoke well of Tom Tehan, and he was genuinely liked by all. As he himself said during the valedictory debate:

It has been said that one of the hallmarks of a successful politician is that he makes some enemies. If that is the litmus test, I have failed as I believe I have made many friends in this place and I leave with no enemies.

After leaving parliament, Tom resumed his law career and was a senior partner at Morrison and Sawers until 1987. He continued his unstinting service to community organisations. The things that were important to Tom Tehan were his family, his church, the law, the National Party and his community.

Tom Tehan will be remembered as a great community leader who unselfishly dedicated most of his life to the betterment of the community of Kyabram. On behalf of the National Party in the Senate I extend most sincere condolences to Nance, his family and many friends.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT ( Senator Patterson)

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Sherry proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's wilful breaking of its promise to the Australian people not to increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes by proposing a new $1.2 billion `Costello sales tax' on the states, territories and local government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the appropriate subtitle for my contribution in leading this debate today is `Six steps of dishonesty and deceit.' Last week, via a surprise press release from the Treasurer, Mr Costello, we had the announcement of a proposed new tax—a $1.2 billion tax—by removing the sales tax exemption on states, territories and local government. It was conveyed via that press release as a fait accompli to the states. This was a decision obviously not taken by the Treasurer, Mr Costello, alone. It was a decision taken by the new government—barely three months old. It was taken by cabinet as a whole. The backbench of the government is very concerned about it. It was taken by cabinet, and by a Prime Minister who likes to refer to himself as Honest John Howard.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision announced by the Costello press release was in fact a repudiation of a number of commitments given by the government prior to the election. It is not just I who asserts that it was a repudiation of promises and commitments given prior to the election. The Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Stockdale, in a wide‐ranging interview, said, amongst other things, that this was a very black day for the new federal government. He said the new government had said they would keep their election promises, and that John Howard had said that he would honour his commitments. Mr Stockdale said:
. . . and here he's broken no less than five commitments, two election promises—no tax increases; this is a tax increase—
He went on in stronger terms when he referred to the proposed agreement in respect of the slightly more than $600 million in general purpose grants by saying:
So the States will be $600 million worse off if this agreement were to be implemented, and that is a flagrant repudiation of not only his election commitments, but the agreement . . .
He went on to say:

I think what we're seeing here is a very bad start by the new Howard government, that they're repudiating fundamental election commitments, they're doing more damage to State taxpayers than even Keating did . . .

During question time today I referred to the commitment given by the now Treasurer, Mr Costello, last year at the National Press Club. I referred to a statement made by the now Assistant Treasurer, Senator Jim Short, making it very clear that there would be no increase in existing taxes and no expansion of existing taxation. Yet last week we had a proposal to increase taxes—$1.2 billion worth of taxes—on just about everything that state, territory and local governments are currently exempt from.

BREAK.PARA: What was the excuse given? Interestingly, in the press release by Treasurer Costello the main emphasis was on alleged rorts in respect of car purchases by state governments and other authorities. This alleged rort was merely an excuse to remove sales tax exemption on libraries, schools, art galleries, Meals on Wheels, marine boards, councils, public transport and child‐care centres operated by local government, to name just a few. The types of articles that would have had their sales tax removed include stationery, videos, computers, photocopiers, books and medical equipment. The list goes on and on. That was the first stage of the deceit and deception.

The second part of the dishonesty of this deception by an arrogant and out of touch Treasurer was in respect of the alleged rorts in the area of motor vehicles. Treasurer Costello put great emphasis on this issue in his ABC radio interview with AM. He said:
. . . we won't allow rorting in the tax system . . . A government that finds rorting shouldn't stand around and say, `Oh, we'll let that go unchecked.'
. . .. to stop rorting and to have transparency in the tax system, governments shouldn't make themselves immune from each other's taxes.

He went on and on about alleged rorts in the tax system. In addition to this proposed $1.2 billion tax being a direct contradiction of promises made prior to the election, it is interesting that, if it was such a big rort, why didn't the now government include it in their list of funding commitments in respect of the last election? The coalition went into some detail about how they were going to fund their election promises. In the document Meeting our commitments there is no mention of sales tax rorts on cars. This $1.2 billion proposal was simply a wilful breaking of election commitments in order to meet the extravagant election promises that the coalition now finds itself having great trouble funding.

Just to compound the errors of the Treasurer, he made a significant error when he claimed in that AM interview of 12 June that Telstra can buy its cars sales tax free. That was a totally untrue claim. So we have an example of the incompetence of the new Treasurer as well as the dishonesty.

The third step in this dishonesty and deceit was to hold, some have said, a sledgehammer—I would have said, more appropriately, a steamroller—over the states by trying to argue that the three-year agreement with the states to maintain general purpose payments was somehow negotiable in the context of this proposed $1.2 billion, when agreement had already been reached with the states and Treasurer Costello was trying to use it as a lever in order to get the states to agree. Again, Treasurer Stockdale from Victoria referred to this in the AM interview when he said:
So the States will be $600 million worse off if this agreement were to be implemented . . .
. . .. the $619 million of grants—they are the second instalment of a three-year agreement which was finalised at last years' Premiers Conference.
So Mr Costello was essentially repudiating the agreement made only 12 months ago.

The fourth level of dishonesty in the new government's approach was the breaching of their commitment on cooperative federalism. Prior to the last election the Liberal Party promised that there would be consultation and discussion with their state colleagues. There was no advance warning or discussion about this new proposal. They were universally condemned by state leaders. In fact, the Treasurer, and now Premier, of my own state, Mr Rundle, said, `Peter Costello's only been there a dog‐watch but in that short time he's making Labor treasurers Willis and Dawkins look good.' That was the fourth area of dishonesty and deceit.

The fifth area of dishonesty and deceit was the outcome of the Premiers Conference, which the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, tried to outline in question time today. There will be various flow-on effects to the states. The states have already announced that there will be increases in taxes and charges and/or a combination of cuts. I see Senator Gibson in the chamber. I remind him of the possible outcomes in Tasmania.

At the beginning of last week the Liberal leaders were looking forward to the Premiers Conference. They thought it was going to be a great show. The only great show they got turned out to be a great dog show. We had the peeved premiers letting loose against Peter Costello, who had been let off the leash. They were like dogs devouring each other in the media, trying to abuse each other. Senator Short smiles, but I am sure Treasurer Costello was not smiling last week.
The final area of dishonesty and deceit was that the Liberals want to introduce a goods and services tax. This is the beginning of the first step towards that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess I ought not to be amazed, but I never do cease to be amazed, at Senator Sherry. I suppose I have to give him full marks for the strength of the nerve and hypocrisy that he brings with him to this chamber in accusing the coalition government of breaking its election commitment of no new taxes. This is an example of the pot calling the kettle black par excellence. I will come back to that later in my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry is wrong in the whole basis of his MPI today. It is a fact that nothing this government has done and nothing the Treasurer (Mr Costello) or anyone else has done has in any way broken the election commitment of no new taxes. It has become a bit of a regular event that each sitting week Senator Sherry comes into this place—a bit like Chicken Little—calls an MPI and claims that the sky is falling in. His last MPI was concerning our so-called ideological fetish with cutting expenditure. The only thing ideological about what is going on is the absolute ideological refusal of the Labor Party to face up to the need for this nation to balance its books—books which were absolutely devastated through 13 years of fiscal vandalism by previous Labor governments. The last MPI was about our so-called ideological fetish with budget restraint. This time it is about our alleged broken promise, broken commitment, that there will be no new taxes.

Once again Senator Sherry is wrong. He is wrong to characterise the sales tax measures contained in the Commonwealth's offer last week to the states as a government breaking its tax promises. We do not resile one iota from the Treasurer's statement on 1 June that the removal of sales tax exemptions for all levels of government would remove a range of anomalies, inequities and distortions.

I see Senator Wheelwright is following Senator Sherry in this debate. I hope that if he does not believe that the sales tax arrangements, so far as they apply to government, in fact give government an unfair advantage compared with their private sector competitors in the area of business, if he does not believe that they do give rise to various rorts of the system, which are publicly identified—I would not want to overstate them, but they are definitely there—if he does not believe that they are anomalous and inequitable in the overall sense of a proper public policy taxation system, he will get up here and say so today.

Senator Sherry certainly did not. Perhaps Senator Wheelwright might, although even then I am not sure what one would read into that, given the massive division, disruption and infighting going on at the moment within the ranks of the Labor Party in terms of ideology. On one hand there is Senator Wheelwright and on the other is Senator Carr. I do not know where Senator Ray is, but I think he is pulling all the strings. Then there is poor old Senator Faulkner sitting here as the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, leader of the Left; he does not have a clue which way he is supposed to go. He will wait like a puppet on a string until all the strings are pulled by the heavyweights around the place, and he will be told what is or is not a good thing to do in terms of taxation reform or budget management.

It is certainly a fact that the removal of sales tax exemptions for government would remove a range of anomalies, inequities and distortions. We do not resile from that, nor do we resile from the fact that the outcome of the Premiers Conference last week, in that sense, produced only a partial tackling of that area of concern. The basic reason for the Premiers Conference proposals of last week, so far as the coalition was concerned, was to come up with a major contribution made by the states and territories in a responsible, cooperative manner to assist the funding and reduction of the $8,000 million deficit that the Howard government inherited from the Keating government when it went out of office on 2 March.

Of course, one of the leading architects in that destruction of the integrity of the Commonwealth's finances was none other than the then Minister for Finance, now the Leader of the Opposition in this parliament, Mr Beazley. If anyone in this present parliament carries the main burden of the blame for what happened to the Commonwealth's finances in the last two or three years, it is surely the Leader of the Opposition.

The opposition, when in government, knew about the anomalies but sought to do nothing at all about them—just as was the case with most of their period of office. They knew, I hope, on occasions, the right thing to do, yet they refused time and time again to grasp the nettle and take some of those decisions—not always palatable or easy decisions—that would make our tax system a fairer system and make Australia, as a result of it, a better place in which to live.

An outcome of the Premiers Conference was to limit the removal of the sales tax exemption where governments provide cars as part of remuneration packages to public servants. It is good that that has happened. I hope that the opposition and the Democrats—I see Senator Spindler here; I have always thought of him as an honourable man in terms of his wishes for a fair and equitable tax system—would agree that that was a correct public policy point to aim for.

As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said, part of the outcome of the Premiers Conference saw the good tax policy measures that were proposed by the coalition last year partly wound back. We do not deny that. The Prime Minister did not resile from the original proposal being good policy, nor did the Treasurer. I am certainly not going to do so now, because we all know that it was good policy. Nevertheless, as I said in question time many times today, the overall outcome of the Premiers Conference was an exceedingly good result for the government.

The key outcome of the Premiers Conference from the Commonwealth's perspective is that the states have agreed to make a substantial contribution towards the task of restoring the Commonwealth budget to balance. It is a balance that has been thrown completely out of kilter by the mismanagement and irresponsibility of the previous Labor government.

The states recognise that the government faces a big fiscal task, which is not the result of the actions of the coalition but rather a reflection of the total fiscal mismanagement of the former Labor government. The states recognise that, in order to fix the problems that we inherited from Labor, the government has to make a lot of tough decisions that we would prefer not to have to make. We are not masochists. We are not political masochists or economic masochists or anything of that nature. What we want to do, though, and we have a responsibility on behalf of the Australian people to do so, is to restore the finances of this nation to proper balance so that we can grow, prosper, create more jobs, reduce unemployment and lower the amount of public debt, and, therefore, the amount of taxes that have to be spent simply on meeting the interest payments on government debt.

In the last four years alone, five years perhaps, the debt of the Commonwealth government has gone up fourfold. That is monstrous, particularly when throughout most of that period we have had economic growth. We should have been running surpluses rather than deficits. But what did we find? We found a Labor government which in that time allowed the debt to escalate fourfold. The impact of that on the interest burden of the budget is enormous, and the interest paid on the debt of the Commonwealth, in the books of the annual budget, is now one of the highest of all items of expenditure.

BREAK.PARA: That is bad policy. It is bad economics. It is very bad economic management. It is—I can say this without hesitation—nothing more than economic vandalism. The states recognise that, just as the new Commonwealth government did.

We are very pleased indeed and have welcomed the fact that the states recognise the need for them to make a contribution to fixing that budget black hole that we inherited from Labor. Payments to the states are a sizeable component of total outlays. It would have been quite unrealistic to quarantine the states—and they appreciate this—from the deficit reduction process.

We are very happy with the final outcome, which we achieved through negotiation. I stress the word `negotiation', because if we are really serious about having a meaningful relationship between Commonwealth and state and territory governments, it can be done only in the sense of people being prepared to get around a table and negotiate.

The fact that your starting position is not always the position that you finish with is absolutely irrelevant. If it were always the case, then the word `negotiation' and the whole concept of conference would have really no meaning.

So we finished up with an agreement by the states to, in full cooperation, make a substantial contribution to the Commonwealth's funding problem over the next three years. That is extremely useful, as is the agreement to remove the exemption from sales tax applying to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of a remuneration package by governments.

We did not roll over at the Premiers Conference. We did not break any promises at the Premiers Conference. We listened to the premiers, because we think that they have a total right to be heard, something that the former Labor government never, ever believed in.

It is amusing to me in the extreme that Senator Sherry would get it so wrong, yet again; broken promises and tax increases are something about which Labor has intricate knowledge. Let me remind the chamber of Labor's top 10 chart busting broken promises when they were in government. No. 10, to maintain the Public Service. What happened? Between 1993 and 1995, the last two to three years of Labor, there was a 2½ per cent reduction in Public Service numbers. Jobs were set to disappear again between 1996 and 1997 under Labor's plan.

No. 9, to maintain majority Australian ownership of Qantas. No. 8, to maintain 51 per cent equity in the Commonwealth Bank. No. 7, to reduce unemployment. Yet the number of people on unemployment benefits is higher now than during the depths of the so-called recession that we had to have. It is higher by a figure of 61,000.

No. 6, to increase spending on Aboriginal health, did not happen. No. 5, to remove all age pensions from the tax system by 1995, did not happen. No. 4, to match the Christmas appeal funds raised by charitable institutions, did not happen. No. 3 was that there were to be no tax increases. What happened? A whole raft of wholesale sales taxes and others spiralled up under Labor. No. 2, to produce self-repairing budgets with a deficit reduction program, was a sad and sick joke. We finished up with Mr Beazley's $8 billion black hole. The daddy of them all, No. 1 of the chart busters, was to provide the l-a-w law cuts. They knew when they made that promise just prior to the 1993 election that they would never keep it. Senator Sherry's proposed matter of public importance is a mass of hypocrisy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very happy to pick up some of the points that Senator Short made. This debate on the matter of public importance seeks to highlight one of the election commitments breached by Mr Costello and Mr Howard during last year's Premiers Conference: namely, the promise not to increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes by proposing a new $1.2 billion Costello sales tax on the states, territories and local governments. According to Mr Alan Stockdale, the Liberal Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Costello had breached no fewer than five separate commitments.

BREAK.PARA: Let me advert to the requests made by Senator Short: namely, the Democrats should wholeheartedly support the plugging of the rorts that are no doubt inherent in this system of sales tax on cars that are provided to public servants and executives. This measure goes well beyond the mere plugging of rorts: it devolves a responsibility of the Commonwealth onto the states. It is merely a shuffling of responsibilities, responsibilities which the Commonwealth government does not want to be seen as having cut in terms of the services provided by the states. It dearly wants to collect the money without taking the blame.

Senator Sherry, who proposed this matter of public importance, knows full well that Labor in government were the past masters of shifting their budgetary problems onto the states. Between 1985 and 1992, the Hawke and Keating governments cut grants to the states in real terms by 19 per cent with a further cut last year. These cuts were partly responsible for the states having to cut over 150,000 jobs in the state public sector and to increase taxes in a wide range of areas.

The Democrats have been a little astounded, I must say, by Mr Costello's definitional gymnastics in recent months about what is or is not a rise in tax. A tariff, we have been told, is a tariff, not a tax. A rise in HECS is a rise in HECS, not a rise in tax on graduates as Senator Vanstone asserted only last year. Now we are told that adding a $1.2 billion tax impost on the states is an attack on rorts and not a rise of $1.2 billion in tax.

Mr Costello's arguments were rejected in very strong terms last week by his state colleagues, who correctly pointed out that his tax grab on the states was an attack on services. But then, this government does not seem to be particularly interested in the impact on the Australian people of its pursuit of the $8 billion budget cuts. Mr Howard and Mr Costello conveniently ignore the fact that the $8 billion cuts are not necessary in economic terms. We all know now that they are in fact based on very rubbery economic growth forecasts, which have already been stretched.

They ignore the fact that $8 billion worth of cuts will hurt an awful lot of Australians through higher charges and lower services. They ignore the impact on the unemployed and the advice of some of Australia's most senior economists such as Fred Argy, John Neville, Fred Gruen and John Quiggin. All that matters is the glowing praise of the financial markets for delivering $8 billion worth of cuts, whether they can be justified in economic terms or not. So Mr Costello and Mr Howard got their $1.5 billion worth of expenditure cuts over the years from the states. The CPSU has estimated that it will mean another 90,000 jobs gone over the next three years or it will mean the states and local authorities will have to increase taxes and charges.

The other interesting thing about Mr Costello's astonishing performance last week was his newfound interest in tax rorts. He said that it was the main reason why he would wish to introduce this particular measure. The Democrats believe that there are many areas in tax rorts where Mr Costello could have made a start and many areas where the Democrats would wholeheartedly support him. An article in last weekend's Australian, written by Mike Steketee, states:

. . . the Keating government announced that it was going to collect $800 million in tax from 100 of the wealthiest Australians who put money through trusts, the advice from the tax office was that 80 of them had assets valued at more than $30 million each but had reported taxable incomes of $20,000 or less.
It is perhaps also important to quote a statement made by Michael Carmody, the tax commissioner. He said:
Put simply, it is difficult to expect the general community to meet their tax responsibilities if they see some high‐wealth individuals paying little or no tax.
The Democrats welcome Mr Costello's newfound interest in tax rorts but we would like him to attack some other areas which are well and truly on the record, such as the ones I have quoted.

We accept that some budget deficit repair will be needed in this year's budget. Labor's unfunded tax cuts and unfunded Working Nation program make this necessary. But we encourage the government to take the advice of Dr Vince FitzGerald in his national savings report, and the suggestion by former EPAC chief Fred Argy that the opportunity for deficit reduction should be used to repair the holes in the revenue base. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I am quite happy to rise in support of Senator Sherry's proposed matter of public importance, particularly as it refers to the coalition government's wilful breaking of promises in relation to taxation in the announcements at the Premiers Conference last week. The first extraordinary thing to occur last week was the great clarion call for microeconomic reform. Last Tuesday, the Treasurer, Mr Costello, came out all hairy‐chested, saying what he was going to do. He was going to demonstrate his competence and courage over microeconomic reform, and his statement on Tuesday was to be the basis for the proposal he was putting to the states. I say `proposal' but I should really say `announcement', which is a distinction that Senator Short was unable to make in question time today. I will read from the announcement issued by the Treasurer:

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of sales tax exemptions for government represents a very important microeconomic and taxation system reform. It will remove inequities and distortions, including the growing abuse of the sales tax exemption by some public sector bodies. Further, it will remove an unfair advantage that many public sector businesses have over private sector competitors who are subject to wholesale sales tax.

That announcement was made last Tuesday and it came out in the style characteristic of Mr Costello. Unfortunately, I cannot quite do his swagger. I do not really need to because a large number of Australians saw his posturing on their television screens.

The announcement, which was drafted by the Treasury, was in relatively sedate language, but the Treasurer was pleased to go further than that in his press conference. He referred to the `unfair advantage' over the private sector and the encouragement for `rorting of the system'. He said that the removal of the sales tax was a `bold move' along the path to microeconomic reform. That was the sort of atmosphere in which these proposals were announced.

BREAK.PARA: I have been heartened by some of the reporting of this matter. People started to become concerned about what might happen at the Premiers Conference and whether the Treasurer might experience some sort of backlash. In response, the Treasurer is reported as saying:

. . . `I've never seen a Premiers' Conference yet where they haven't said the world will fall in. And you know what happens, after the Premiers' Conference is over: the sun comes up, as it always did'.

That was the picture of the Treasurer last Tuesday and Wednesday. But we are all very much indebted to Mr John Short who, by probably trying to qualify for this year's Walkley Award, gave us the real details of how these negotiations took place. He gave us the behind the scenes story of exactly how this bold microeconomic reform was transacted. I read from his article in the Australian of last Saturday:

The high drama of the opening day of the premiers' conference on Thursday over the attempt by the federal Treasurer, Mr Costello, to hit the States with a $1.2 billion sales tax bill was replaced yesterday by high farce.

The premiers left the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and his Treasurer on Thursday night with an offer that would have seen substantial cuts in federal grants to fund general services in return for Mr Costello's sales tax bill being sliced back to $100 million.
The States' offer was to apply for two years to help the Commonwealth deliver a balanced Budget in 1997‐98.
Mr Howard then made a counter‐offer which would have seen the States' generous offer being effectively extended for another six months.
A number of the premiers were of the view that the Prime Minister had said that if they accepted this new version, then they would have a deal.
So, when they arrived at Parliament House—
on Friday—
for a scheduled 9.30am meeting, they were expecting that a deal would be quickly done.
