TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Securi ty)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on officer education in the Australian Defence Force. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Government Response to Officer Education: The Military After Next Report on The System of Professional Military Development of Officers in the ADF by The Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Executive Summary

The Report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, entitled Officer Education: The Military After Next , was tabled on 23 October 1995. The Joint Standing Committee's inquiry arose as a consequence of the issue of the provision of academic studies and professional military education to officer cadets and officers of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) being referred by the Minister for Defence on 22 June 1993. This referral by the Minister closely followed the completion of the Program Evaluation of the Australian Defence Force Academy (henceforth referred to as the `Academy') by the Inspector-General in December 1992. Terms of Reference for the Committee inquiry are at Appendix A, and membership of the Defence Sub-Committee is at Appendix B.

The Committee attempted to ascertain whether the existing system of officer development `remains adequate for preparing officers who will encounter a fundamentally different set of global, regional and national security arrangements'.1 These changed environmental factors are embodied in the concept of the `military after next'.2 Defence has accepted this concept as a most useful tool in the formulation of strategic policy and future architecture for the ADF's professional military development and academic education of its officer corps. It is noted that, whilst the Terms of Reference limited the inquiry and the subsequent report to the provision of academic education and professional military studies at nine Defence colleges, the system of professional military development and academic education of officers is not limited to these nine colleges.

Four key themes are evident in the Report: the role of the ADF in the next century; the cost of educating and training officers at various points in their careers; the `closed' societal system represented by officer education within the Academy, and the need for greater effort by Defence to create a `total force' by enhancing `jointery', integration of regular and reserve forces, and closer collaboration between military personnel and civilians.

The Response has been prepared by an ADF Working Party consisting of representatives from Headquarters ADF, Department of Defence, the single Services and both the University College and Military Component of the Defence Academy. The tenor of the Response is, by intent, reflecting that of Defence, with more specific delineation of views only where appropriate. The Response addresses the 23 Recommendations sequentially, with 3 supported, 7 supported in principle, 2 supported in part, 1 under examination and 10 not supported.
The Key Responses are as follows:
. Supported —1, 2, 3
. Supported in Principle —4, 6, 7, 9, 10, 15, 23
. Supported in Part —5, 8
. Under Examination —17
RESPONSES TO RECOMMENDATIONS
The Committee recommends that:
. consistent with the Inspector General's report of 1992, the ADF introduce a comprehensive policy on higher education for officers; and
. this policy be introduced by the end of 1996.
RESPONSE

The intention is for Headquarters Australian Defence Force to compile, in consultation with the Services, the Department and the Australian Defence Force Academy (ADFA), an ADF Policy on higher education for officers to the year 2010. This draft policy will be ready for Chiefs of Staff Committee consideration in the latter half of 1996, and introduction as soon as possible thereafter.
The Committee recommends that the ADF adopt the policy of accrediting appropriate civilian training and coursework for military purposes.
RESPONSE

The recognition of appropriate civilian gained competencies towards the completion of Service courses is already practised by the ADF. Distinct from this process is the civilian recognition of Australian Defence Force training according to the National Framework for the Recognition of Training, a process otherwise known as `accreditation'. These processes together facilitate a smooth transition from military to civilian life and vice versa. Defence requires officers to hold civilian qualifications (eg Engineering, Medicine, Dentistry, Law etc), in order to meet their military job requirements.

Defence therefore supports this recommendation, to take maximum advantage of civilian education content. However, it must be stated that civilian qualifications cannot totally replace ADF training for key core roles, particularly those concerning military skills. The knowledge, skills and attitudes required of personnel in some fields of military employment are developed by specific ADF courses. These courses are designed to attain vocational competencies that are not necessarily intrinsic in civilian training and coursework.
The Committee recommends that officers in each Service be regularly notified of all postings.
RESPONSE

Defence will seek to progressively implement an electronic mailing system to expedite the distribution of personnel information to all officers. The system will include on-line access to existing officer posting data, updates on new positions, opportunities to apply for `advertised' posts, and other information relating to officer postings. The ready accessibility of career planning information via the electronic mailing system will enable officers to consider their options, make recommendations for future postings based on comprehensive information, and enable identification of posts for which they will need further appropriate training.

The Committee recommends that at each stage of pre-commissioning and post-commissioning officer training, course content include education in citizenship, Australia's democratic processes, the rule of law, the individual's equality before the law, the relationship between policing and military responsibilities and the civil‐military relationship.
RESPONSE

Defence supports the concept that officers should be educated in citizenship, Australia's democratic processes, the rule of law, the individual's equality before the law, the relationship between policing and military responsibilities and the civil/military relationship. Some education of this type is already provided, as noted by the Committee at paragraph 14.32. Most of the current education in these areas occurs as a component of the lengthier professional development courses (eg mid-senior level staff courses). There may be potential to supplement junior officer staff courses and pre-commissioning training with this content. Because of the strict resource and time constraints on these shorter courses, however, it will be necessary to determine the precise level of content of each subject that is most appropriate and the extent of possible increases in resources to accommodate inclusion of such material.
The Committee recommends that recognition be given to appropriate academic qualifications, such as Master of Defence Studies, Graduate Diploma in Strategic Studies, in the awards of psc and jssc .
RESPONSE

Defence supports the concept of recognition of appropriate civilian gained academic qualifications towards the completion of professional development courses, especially where such recognition facilitates integration of Reserve Officers in the Total Force. It does not support the granting of complete exemption for such academic qualifications, in the award of the psc and jssc . These professional courses include specific military content that is not a component of civilian courses. Where possible, Defence believes that credit towards completion of modules of professional courses is desirable. The respective staff courses will be examined as part of a Defence strategic review of professional military development, to determine which modules are appropriate for such recognition, and the capacity for further modularisation of those courses. Other issues that need to be addressed include the rate of progression of students who have exemption for certain modules, and how to preserve the esprit de corps of staff college student bodies. The cost effectiveness of conducting individual streams of study to accommodate all students will also need to be addressed.

The Committee recommends that modules of the professional military studies, equivalent to single Service staff college and Joint Services Staff College professional military studies components, be developed.
RESPONSE

Defence supports the principle that officers who miss the window of opportunity to attend single Service staff college or Joint Services Staff College be able to be accredited with the academic competencies of those respective courses. This may be able to be done through the modularisation of course components, delivery of some modules by distance education, and the attendance of students at short residential schools. What they may not be able to be accredited with is the award of psc or jssc . This is because these awards encompass competencies that are only gained through full-time staff work and course work that involves the whole student body.

Headquarters Australian Defence Force will examine, in concert with the Services, the impact of alternative delivery methods of professional studies material at psc and jssc level on the professional military development continuum, as part of the formulation process of an ADF over-arching strategic policy on professional military development.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force review the officer education system to identify where alternative delivery methods such as distance education can be implemented.
RESPONSE

Defence supports the need for further investigation of all the opportunities for alternative delivery methods of professional officer education programs. Flexibility in delivery methods, particularly the use of distance education, can offer individuals increased choice in how and when they complete courses, it can reduce training costs and it can reduce posting turbulence. The Australian Defence Force Training System provides for the review of delivery methods as part of the regular course review process. However, it should be noted that staff college course content is such that distance learning cannot completely replace all the learning outcomes.

The Committee recommends that attendance at the colleges continue to be determined by rank but, in appropriate circumstances, recognition of function may be taken into account to permit senior captains to attend the Staff and Command Colleges.
RESPONSE

Navy allows officers of senior Captain (E) rank to attend the RAN Staff Course as the aim of this course is to prepare officers for staff appointments at both the Major(E) and Lieutenant Colonel(E) rank. However, Army specifically uses the Command and Staff Course (C&SC) to prepare Majors for command and staff appointments in the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. Captains and Majors are at different points on the professional development continuum; Captains are involved in high skill orientated tasks whilst Majors are more heavily involved with indirect command, leadership and management. If Captains attended the C&SC there would be a significant period between training and education and the application of knowledge and skills. To allow senior Captains to be posted to the C&SC based on their future job function would be inappropriate, given the current context and specific aims of the Command and Staff Course within the professional training continuum. Air Force, like Army, uses its Command and Staff Course to prepare MAJ(E) officers for performance at the LTCOL(E) level in command and demanding staff appointments. Within the Air Force Officer Education and Training Scheme suite of courses there is another course specifically tailored to the needs of CAPT(E) officers to prepare them for promotion to MAJ(E). Consequently, Defence can only support this recommendation as appropriate to Navy, but not appropriate to either Army or Air Force.
The Committee recommends that the ADF review regulations governing removals and related entitlements for officers posted on professional development courses.
RESPONSE

The removal entitlements for members of the ADF are dependent on the length of a posting. Postings vary from less than six months, through an intermediate term posting of six to less than twelve months, to a long term posting of twelve months or more. Changes to current removal and reunion travel policies to accommodate all categories of personnel would have widespread implications. In view of the significant conditions of service implications of this recommendation, Defence will review the issues to determine what, if any, amendments and/or policy changes may be indicated.
The Committee recommends that the number of ADF places on each staff course offered by the colleges be increased.
RESPONSE
Supported in Principle

As each staff course is purposely designed to equip officers for specific Service requirements, current course sizes are consistent with the numbers needed to meet those requirements. Notwithstanding this balance, Defence accepts that it is desirable to expand education opportunities in the officer corps, for both regular and reserve officers, within the limit of available resources. Nevertheless there are a number of factors which, taken in concert, reduce the practicality of this recommendation:

. An increase in the number of ADF placements on each staff course would significantly impact on the manning of senior officer posts within the Services. Unless Funded Average Strength for the Australian Defence Force was increased or a reduction in Force capability accepted, the Services would have no scope to release officers for additional staff course placements. Further more, additional college staff and facilities would be required to support larger course numbers.

. The recommendation would be achievable by reducing the number of placements currently offered to foreign forces, the Australian Public Service and other agencies. However, to do so would be counter-productive to the aim of fostering closer professional links with regional defence forces, facilitating regional engagement and providing a diversity of professional backgrounds and experience.

A more viable means of improving staff course participation might rely on the introduction of distance based modular learning, as proposed at Recommendations 6 and 7. The extent to which this can be realised is to be examined, as detailed in the responses to those recommendations.

The Committee recommends that the ADF conduct a feasibility study into the establishment of a tri-Service pre-commissioning college with appropriate single Service elements to replace the existing single-Service pre-commissioning colleges.
RESPONSE

Defence does not support the conduct of a feasibility study into the establishment of a tri-Service precommissioning college, as the existing separate colleges are well suited to the delivery of training that encompasses leadership styles, operational environments and routines that are peculiar to the respective Services. In particular, whilst Navy and Air Force use their pre-commissioning training for initial training only, with more specialist application training to follow, Army use pre-commissioning training to prepare officers for command of a platoon-sized group in action or training without close supervision. Pre-commissioning training cannot be considered in isolation from the subsequent training process in each of the three Services.
The Committee recommends that the ADF establish a review of junior officer development to assess, among other things, the balance between military professional development and war fighting skills.
RESPONSE

This recommendation comprises three elements. These are: professional military development, specialist military skills, and exposure to the principles of jointery and joint operations. Professional military development training is closely related to job requirements. The ADF systems approach to training ensures that training is derived directly from job requirements using precision occupational analysis methods, and is accurately targeted at specific task performance. Likewise, the training system ensures that, for junior officer training, there is an effective balance between professional military development and specialist military (war-fighting) skills. The joint war-fighting skills of various specialisations are met by the provision of role-specific courses. The demands of learning single Service operational and war-fighting skills dominate training requirements for junior officers in all three Services. Whilst the need for joint war-fighting skills varies between specialisations, nevertheless, the respective Services effectively meet all joint training requirements. The continued maintenance of an adequate level of joint training can be assured through the application of normal training processes. In addition, the Chiefs of Staff Committee periodically review the overall structure of the professional military development continuum in order to ensure that the blend of tactical and operational training requirements for all officers remains appropriate for the command and operational environment of the ADF. Defence will include in its strategic review of officer professional military development, an analysis of any further scope for broader general `jointery' training for junior officers beyond individual specialisation, category or corps requirements. As a consequence, the establishment of a separate dedicated review, as proposed in this recommendation, is not justified nor would such a review be consistent with the holistic approach proposed by Defence.
The Committee recommends that:
(a) the RAN Staff College, the Army Command and Staff College and the RAAF Command and Staff College be integrated into a single tri-Service ADF Command and Staff College located in Canberra; and

(b) the integration of the RAN Staff College, the Army Command and Staff College and the RAAF Command and Staff College into a single tri-Service ADF Command and Staff College with appropriate single-Service elements be phased in over the next two to three years.
RESPONSE

The Chiefs of Staff Committee review of professional military education for ADF officers in May 1994 agreed on an amended charter for the three staff colleges, which emphasised single Service requirements and training at the tactical level of war. The review also identified that, whilst there were no training imperatives for integration of the staff colleges, nevertheless, there was potential for some economies of scale to be gained from collocation in the medium term. From the facilities aspect, it is now recognised that in the medium to long term, reinvestment in the three Staff Colleges is necessary. The Air Force facility is recognised as requiring upgrading in the near term. Possible collocation of the respective staff colleges at one site therefore warrants further consideration by Defence. Defence does not support the full integration of the single Service Staff Colleges.

The development of an optimum model for a collocated facility requires the resolution of issues such as core curriculum, duration of course and desired balance of single Service specific modules with common modules. A strategic policy on ADF Officer Professional Military Development will provide this guidance. The intention is therefore to develop the policy on Professional Military Development by the end of 1996 and use the policy to guide the feasibility study of a collocated Staff College facility. Subject to the feasibility of such a facility being established, the intention is to then prepare a Major Capability Submission on the staged delivery of a collocated single Service Staff College facility.
The Committee recommends that, on balance, the University College undergraduate program conducted at ADFA be terminated.
RESPONSE

Defence does not support the adoption of the Committee's proposal to terminate undergraduate education at the Academy. The Report lacks substantive and sufficiently detailed reasoning to justify such a proposal. To accept it would involve the abandoning of a system in which both the Australian Defence Force and University of New South Wales have made a significant investment, and which is known to provide a high quality product, in favour of an alternative with an untested capacity to meet the quantitative and qualitative needs of Defence. Termination of the undergraduate program at the Academy would remove 1000 places from the higher education system. To maintain current levels of opportunity for university studies in Australia through provision of equivalent additional places in other institutions within the National Unified System would cost $10 million.

The Committee's proposal is not based on any perceived military or academic deficiencies but on the perception that `an education at ADFA may not be an appropriate mechanism for integrating officer cadets with the community they are going to serve'.3 There are significant advantages for Defence in retaining undergraduate education at the Academy:
. The preservation of an environment in which the military ethos and culture of the profession of arms can be instilled in young officer cadets.
. The provision of a tri-Service environment for officer cadets at an early stage in their professional training.
. The provision of a guaranteed and manageable flow of entrants into the officer corps.
. The opportunity for young Australians to combine a serious commitment to a military career with the attainment of a high quality university degree.

Nevertheless, Defence is conscious of the value in further examining how best to educate officers both prior to commissioning and throughout their careers. It is also mindful of the cost of such education and the importance of relative costings in the likely continued environment of highly constrained defence budgets. Relative costings can drive not only recruiting patterns but also the relative importance of the various entry modes to the ADF Officer Corps. Defence intends to initiate a review of its officer education and professional military studies system (as discussed in the responses to Recommendations 1 and 13). This review will consider the likely impact of sociological, technological and strategic changes over the next 15-20 years on the relative effectiveness of the various recruitment and officer training schemes, including the Academy. The intention of the review will not be to replace undergraduate education at the Academy but rather to adapt existing entry and training schemes in order that Defence can best recruit, educate and train its officer corps into the 21st century.
The Committee recommends that the amounts paid to students pursuant to the Undergraduate Scheme be reviewed.
RESPONSE

Defence considers it appropriate that the Undergraduate Scheme should be reviewed to assess whether the current scheme satisfies required outcomes and to determine if more effective procedures and practices could be implemented. A review should examine all aspects of the service conditions of the Undergraduate Scheme, not just pay levels. Despite the apparently high level of financial support for the Undergraduate Scheme, the Services still have difficulty attracting sufficient recruits to the scheme. The Undergraduate Scheme is the only viable method of specialist recruitment of professionals such as doctors and dentists, and any review must include pertinent input from qualified Service practitioners in these fields. The recruitment and retention of medical officers is a special area of concern which deserves separate consideration in a review of the Undergraduate Scheme.

While a review of the scheme in isolation may prove valuable, it should be viewed in the total context of officer education and development as discussed at Recommendations 1, 14 and 16. Issues that need to be addressed include cost effectiveness, quality of applicants, whether sufficient numbers of applicants are attracted, which specialisations are recruited, and any adjustment problems faced by Undergraduate Scheme officers following training. It is also relevant that the review should take into account the difficulty in attracting required undergraduates and graduates, and examine the rates of comparable industry scholarships.
The Committee recommends that the undergraduate program at ADFA be replaced by an Undergraduate Sponsorship Scheme with the following features:
(a) selection of 1,000 undergraduate students per year by a Selection Board, and prior to entry into university, the completion of an initial basic single Service training course;
(b) students each year will be assessed on both academic and military performance;
(c) sponsorship amounts:
- First year $6,000
- Second year $6,500
- Third year $7,000
- Fourth year $8,000
and in addition provide an appropriate allowance for items including books, course‐related equipment and, where necessary, accommodation;
(d) single Service and common military training each year during extended academic breaks;
(e) final selection of officer cadets by the ADF on a competitive basis upon the completion of undergraduate courses.
RESPONSE

Defence examination of this recommendation has highlighted that adoption of the proposed Undergraduate Sponsorship Scheme represents a significant gamble, being combined as it is with the termination of undergraduate entry through the Academy. There is no clear indication that the proposed scheme would be either as workable or successful as postulated by the Report. Indeed, it would appear that the proposed scheme sacrifices many of the synergistic advantages of a single institution such as the Academy, without offering compensating tangible benefits. The principle reasons for doubting the viability of the proposed scheme are:

. The level of graduate unemployment is difficult to predict over the next 5 years let alone into the 21st century. The number of graduates and potential graduates who might be interested in committing themselves to the profession of arms (as distinct from accepting a scholarship) may be extremely variable.

. Experience with both the Undergraduate Scheme and with direct entry graduates indicates that in order to get the best graduates the ADF will have to compete with the very attractive salary packages offered by the private sector. The financial constraints on the Defence budget do not permit such competition. The quality of graduate who will take up ADF employment therefore becomes somewhat problematic.

. The proposed scheme does not readily offer the mechanism by which the ADF can regulate the number of graduates in the required disciplines, nor easily ensure that particular specialisations are recruited in the desired proportions.

. The sole reliance on a scheme that seeks to recruit undergraduates whilst at university leaves Defence recruitment at the mercy of not only societal attitudes to military service but also the complex interaction of political factors operating in university campuses around the country.

The Sponsorship Scheme will also undermine the existing Undergraduate Scheme, effectively reducing the management flexibility that Defence presently has in regulating the various entry modes to the officer corps. In summary, Defence doubts that the proposed Sponsorship Scheme would attract sufficient number of graduates, of the right quality, in the right proportions and at the right time. Therefore Defence cannot support the proposal as it stands. What Defence proposes is to examine the viability of implementing an extended university-based recruitment scheme in parallel with refinements to the conduct of undergraduate and postgraduate education at the Academy. This is in order to achieve cost efficiencies and best position the ADF to fully exploit changing patterns of undergraduate and graduate entry to the ADF over the next 20 years.
The Committee recommends that the 1981 Agreement between the University of New South Wales and the Commonwealth of Australia be re-negotiated.
RESPONSE

As noted by the Committee Report, the Program Evaluation of the Academy in 1992 concluded that the Agreement does not define clearly the rights and obligations of each party. In short, changes are needed to the Agreement and the resultant `improvements in transparency and accountability will be to the benefit of both UNSW and Defence'.4 Defence is to review its undergraduate and postgraduate education requirements for its officer corps into the 21st century, the roles and functions of the University College, and the related 1981 Agreement will be addressed as part of this review.
This examination process will also involve the University of New South Wales (UNSW). Some areas of the Agreement which may require further examination are:
. Clarification and formalising of funding review provisions at Clause 8.2.
. The format of the Agreement be more consistent with public sector management arrangements, clearly specifying Defence requirements.5
. The scope of postgraduate education and distance learning programs, and the inclusion of Defence requirements for such programs.
. Reference to membership of the Academy Council be updated to reflect forthcoming changes to Chiefs of Staff titles.
. The Agreement should reflect the introduction of performance criteria against expenditure and funding levels.

These and other issues will be examined in more detail in concert with the UNSW, in order to determine the extent of any formal review process and to determine whether renegotiation of the Agreement is needed.
The Committee recommends that undergraduate courses at ADFA cease at the end of 1999.
RESPONSE
This recommendation flows on from Recommendation 14 that is Not Supported. If undergraduate education at ADFA is not terminated, then this recommendation is redundant.
The Committee recommends that the Undergraduate Sponsorship Scheme be introduced at the start of 1997.
RESPONSE
This recommendation is linked to Recommendation 16 which is Not Supported. Therefore this recommendation is redundant.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force Academy be expanded to include the Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies, the Joint Services Staff College and the tri-Service ADF Command and Staff College.
RESPONSE

The Committee, in its discussion of this recommendation, presupposes that University College will not conduct undergraduate education and, therefore, there may be economies of scale to be achieved in utilising the available facilities for other purposes. As Recommendations 13 and 14 are not supported there will not be excess facilities at the Academy for locating the institutions referred to in this Recommendation. In addition, Defence is not satisfied that there are any additional functional efficiencies to be gained from relocating the Joint Services Staff College (JSSC) and Australian College of Defence and Strategic Studies (ACDSS) to a new facility, over and above the efficiencies already gained by having the JSSC and ACDSS collocated at the Weston Creek site. Recent experience with the ACDSS facilities program indicates that the cost for establishing a new facility for both ACDSS and JSSC would be in the order of $15M. Because of the decision to retain undergraduate education at the Academy, and given the functional efficiencies already gained by collocating JSSC/ACDSS at Weston Creek, Defence cannot support this recommendation.
The Committee recommends that a Graduate School of Defence Studies be expanded so as to incorporate the existing post graduate programs at the Australian Defence Force Academy.
RESPONSE

While the University College of the Australian Defence Force Academy may be the `university of first choice' for Defence, it is by no means the only university being used by members of Defence for post graduate study. Other universities provide strategic and defence related studies. To structure ADF postgraduate study programs on the Academy, which would be the outcome of forming a `centre of excellence', would undoubtedly attract adverse attention from tertiary institutions Australia wide, especially those with particular ties to the Services.

Further, the University College provides an extensive postgraduate program for Defence members, and welcomes full fee paying civilian students. The scope of the programs offered extends beyond the description of `Defence Studies'. Although the University College's pilot program into distance education is in the Defence Studies field, this program is planned to encompass other fields of study. Limiting the Academy to just Defence Studies would remove a cost effective avenue for Defence to provide needed postgraduate education for its members in disciplines such as computer, engineering and management sciences.

The functions that would be undertaken by a Graduate School of Defence Studies are already catered for by the University College. Renaming the College as a Graduate School of Defence Studies would not be descriptive of the range of studies currently undertaken by the existing postgraduate programs. Any measure to narrow the postgraduate function of the University College would undoubtedly have a negative effect on the ability of the College to attract valuable research funding. For all these reasons, Defence does not support this recommendation.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force Academy be established under an Australian Defence Force Academy Act.
RESPONSE

The introduction of new legislation is a major and complex undertaking that should only be considered when there are no other options. The Committee's justification for recommending the establishment of an Australian Defence Force Academy Act is unclear. Whether legislation is needed depends on the composition and function of the Academy.
If the Academy consists of nothing more than elements of the Australian Defence Force, there is no obvious requirement for legislation.

. If the Academy remains associated with the University of New South Wales, there appears to be adequate legislative cover under the latter's 1968 State Act (and no evident scope for additional Commonwealth legislation).

. If the Academy were to be a free-standing educational institution, not part of the Australian Defence Force and detached from the University of New South Wales, there would be a need for legislation—but this is essentially the concept that was rejected 15 years ago after the Public Works Committee report on the Defence Academy.
For the above reasons Defence does not support the recommendation.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force Academy foster awards for excellence of achievement in defence.
RESPONSE

Defence supports the recognition of outstanding academic achievement, including research, in the area of defence. The Australian Defence Force Academy currently provides prizes and awards in recognition of academic excellence by students at the University College. A Chief of the Defence Force Scholarship has now been established to
encourage excellence in defence related research and provide the opportunity for further study at the Academy.

This recommendation will require further examination to define the extent and nature of the awards proposed by the Committee in its report, and to identify the most appropriate means of conferring recognition for excellence of achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 13 February 1991, I present the bilateral treaty and subsidiary agreement between the government of Australia and the government of Japan concerning tuna long‐line fishing, together with national interest analysis and statement of explanation as to the need for the implementation of the treaty. These documents were presented to Senator Calvert as Temporary Chairman of Committees on 7 June 1996 and, in accordance with the terms of the resolution, the publication of the documents was authorised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to pay tribute to my colleague Senator Parer for obtaining the position of Minister for Resources and in doing so bringing to a head the long running dispute between the Australian and Japanese governments over southern bluefin tuna. It was having a particular effect on my state of Tasmania and the port of Hobart because, as part of the dispute between the Japanese and Australian governments, there was a boycotting of ports which meant that provedores involved in supplying provisions to the Japanese tuna boats that come into Hobart lost a fair amount of money. The provision of services to the Japanese fishing boats is worth quite a few million dollars to the port of Hobart.

SPEECH.PARA: The dispute was over the setting of the global catch quota. The Japanese wanted to increase that by 6,000 tonnes on an experimental basis to prove that the actual adult stock was improving in size. The Australian government does not believe that there is enough evidence yet to show that depleted adult stocks of southern bluefin tuna are recovering to sufficient levels to increase fishing. So we had this stand off between Australia and Japan in signing this annual treaty. But I am pleased to say that because of the work of members of the department and the leadership of my colleague Senator Parer we are now able to bring this treaty to fruition and cut a lot of red tape.

I, as temporary chairman, had the pleasure of signing on behalf of the Senate the agreements that were tabled here today. Some 55 boats are eligible to be fishing in the very rich area of the east coast of Tasmania. No more than 55 fishing licences are allowed to be used at any one time in that area. I do not need to remind the Senate of the value of the catch of tuna when it is presented to the Tokyo fish market.

For many years now I have been amazed why there has not been any attempt to establish a similar type of industry to the Japanese longlining. It would seem to be a lucrative industry that perhaps some Australian fishermen could adapt to. I am pleased to say that there are now five fishermen, which could grow to even more, in Hobart who are longline tuna fishing in a similar fashion to the Japanese which means that we have a Tasmanian or Australian based industry exporting chilled tuna into the Tokyo fish market thanks to the very good freight set up that has been established because of the salmon industry in Tasmania. That will allow tuna that is caught one day to arrive at the Tokyo fish market within 48 hours. So one can understand this new enterprise, which is in its very early days in Hobart, will hopefully contribute to the port of Hobart and also to the income of people of Tasmania.

I was very pleased to be part of this very important process. The Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna establishes a commission for the conservation of the tuna and to manage the species on a global basis. The treaty is a bilateral agreement. There are very strict guidelines and many government agencies are involved.

In fact, the Australian government goes to great lengths to protect the fishing zones that are used by the Japanese and it goes to great lengths to ensure that Japanese fishermen comply with the conservation and regulatory requirements. That includes compulsory use of satellite vessel monitoring systems, daily catch and position reporting, fisheries observer coverage and seabird bycatch mitigation measures—tori poles, which keep our albatross away from the lines when the bait is being laid. Australian fishermen have been using these devices but this year is the first time the Japanese have been forced to use them.

This is a good result and, once again, I would like to commend all those officers who were involved in the very delicate negotiations and, in particular, the minister for bringing the matter to a head.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 41st Common wealth Parliamentary Conference and to make a short statement in relation to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation to the 41st Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, held at Colombo, Sri Lanka, in October 1995. The conference was preceded by a meeting of the executive committee and a small countries conference. The report is slightly out of date because the conference was held in October 1995. Things move slowly in the Senate, and I am now giving the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth of Australia delegation comprised Senator Nick Minchin; Senator Christabel Chamarette; Jim Snow, a member before the recent election was held; and Kathy Sullivan, member for Moncrieff, who was the deputy leader. As a regional representative of the CPA for the Australian region, I led the delegation and attended the meeting of the executive committee.

The conference was attended by some 250 delegates from 100 Commonwealth countries. Representatives from all Australian states and territories attended the conference so that together we made a substantial Australian contribution. I took the initiative to hold several informal meetings of all the Australians to provide feedback on executive committee matters and to discuss a consistent approach to various aspects and issues. This proved to be very worth while.

The theme of the conference was `Democracy and development: adversaries or allies?' In line with the practice developed since 1992, the emphasis was on the panel session, where more informal discussions took place. Jim Snow was invited to be a panel member at one of the sessions and other delegates were able to make contributions both at the panel session and at the conference plenary.

The Commonwealth Secretary General, Chief Emeka Anyaoku, addressed the conference on the challenges and the opportunities facing the Commonwealth at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, which was due to take place in Auckland shortly after the conference. He focused in particular on ways in which the Commonwealth can achieve practical results in fulfilling the principles in the Harare Commonwealth declaration, especially in upholding democratic values within their own countries.

The general assembly of the CPA met at the beginning of the conference and agreed to the formation of branches in seven South African provinces. Representatives of those branches attended the conference and were welcomed by the delegates. At a later stage, I was lucky enough to attend the executive meeting in Cape Town, which was very well run and which showed that the country of South Africa was moving well and truly towards the democratic constitution that was being discussed at that time.

The conference does not have the power to pass resolutions or to agree to communiques expressing a particular position. However, at this conference the Hon. Ngereteina Puna, of the Cook Islands, and I were instrumental in the presentation of a petition expressing concern about the testing of nuclear weapons by France and China. While the part of the petition dealing with France is now out of date, the part dealing with China is still very much in vogue. The petition endorsed a declaration made earlier in the year by the Australian‐Pacific Regional Conference of the CPA and called on France to sign and ratify the protocols of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Whilst the report says that the petition was signed by more than 100 delegates at the conference, I believe the number was closer to 200. The Commonwealth Secretary‐General agreed to convey the petition to Auckland for the attention of the Commonwealth heads of government.

The Commonwealth Women Parliamentarians Group conducted its seventh meeting in conjunction with the conference. For the first time, no other conference events were scheduled at the time of the meeting. This meant that I and other members of the CPA executive could attend and lend support to the group.

The conference proceeded without a hitch, despite the uncertainties presented by the continuing conflict in Sri Lanka. The Sri Lanka branch and its secretariat are to be congratulated on their achievements.

I thank the Australian high commissioner in Sri Lanka for his assistance during the conference. He and his staff provided briefings and news from Australia and helped arrange a reception hosted by Australia and New Zealand. The Sri Lankan high commission here in Australia also provided invaluable assistance and hospitality to the delegation prior to and after the visit of the delegation. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Sri Lanka and to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Sri Lanka between 3 and 6 October 1995. This delegation's visit to Sri Lanka was quite a short one—only four days—before attending the Commonwealth parliamentary conference held in Colombo, which Senator Jones just referred to. It was a successful visit.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation members for this visit were Mr Jim Snow, the former member for Eden Monaro, as leader; Mrs Kathy Sullivan, as deputy leader; Senator Chamarette; and me. Despite what you read in the papers, Australia is a more dangerous place for politicians than is Sri Lanka, as is evident from the fact that we survived whatever risks there were in Sri Lanka but half the delegation subsequently lost their places in the Australian parliament at the federal election. I pass on my regrets to Senator Chamarette and Mr Snow.

The visit to Sri Lanka took place from 3 to 6 October last year and was the first visit there since 1986. At the time of the visit there had been considerable change in Sri Lanka and there was hope for a resolution to the long‐running conflict between the government of Sri Lanka and militant Tamil groups, most prominently the LTTE. Even though we had only four days in Sri Lanka, we were able to meet with a wide range of people and talk about prospects for an end to the war and about trade and investment matters in Sri Lanka.

We met with a considerable number of ministers of the government, including the famous Prime Minister, Mrs Bandaranaike, who became the first woman Prime Minister in the world in 1960. It was an honour to meet her. In all the meetings we had with ministers and opposition party leaders, there was clearly a genuine commitment within the Sri Lankan parliament to achieving peace. However, it must be noted that the refusal of the LTTE to participate in negotiation on the reform proposals put forward by the Sri Lankan government put the prospects for peace in doubt. The LTTE's persistence in terrorist activity, rather than coming to the negotiation table, has led to a loss of credibility for that organisation in the international community and obviously has placed great hardship on the people of Sri Lanka.

Australia and Sri Lanka have enjoyed a very long and warm bilateral relationship based on strong Commonwealth links, wartime links and a flow of Sri Lankan migrants to Australia. We believe our visit consolidated that relationship. Trade and investment have been an important part of the relationship. We saw a number of opportunities for Australian investment in Sri Lanka and were able to discuss several existing projects. Despite the brief duration of the visit, we were able to see and talk to a number of people and see for ourselves the need for infrastructure development to support the growth in trade. I note in passing an advertisement in today's Australian for its Sri Lanka country survey that will appear in November 1996. Its reflections on Sri Lanka were pertinent to this report. The Australian said:

. . . the country should be seen as one which has managed to establish fiscal discipline in the national economy. With GDP growth expected to top 6.0 per cent in 1996, Sri Lanka has created an environment for foreign investment that is among the most attractive in South Asia. It also has one of the highest literacy and English‐language competency rates in the region, and has instituted a birth control program aimed to help the nation break out of its poverty trap.

President Chandrika Kumaratunga has continued the privatisation program which marked her first year in office. This provides Sri Lanka with prospects for 1996 much better than even recent years. The government has also promised no new taxes.
I think that reflects the confidence which people increasingly have in Sri Lanka's future.

In closing I would like record the delegation's thanks to everyone that we met with in Sri Lanka. At all meetings and inspections the delegation heard the frank views of the people we met and received very generous and warm hospitality. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank, in particular, the then Australian High Commissioner, Mr Bill Tweddell, and his wife for their hospitality, support and cooperation. I should congratulate Australia's foreign minister, Mr Alexander Downer, on appointing Mr Tweddell as his chief of staff. They will make a great team for this country.

On behalf of the delegation, I would also like to thank the staff of the High Commission, particularly Mr Dominic Trindade, who organised the itinerary and accompanied the delegation throughout Sri Lanka. The assistance and support provided by the High Commissioner and his staff were of the first order. The Sri Lankan High Commissioner in Canberra also provided tremendous assistance to the delegation and to the delegation to the parliamentary meeting. Their generous hospitality was very much appreciated. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

It was a very memorable visit to Sri Lanka for me, and I support the comments that have been made. The hospitality and entertainment were truly wonderful. Seneviratne, for his preparatory and follow‐up evenings which assisted both the planning and experiences of the delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: Thanks too to the Australian High Commission which, as Senator Minchin already mentioned, were exemplary in the service and care provided not only to us as visitors but also, as was demonstrated, to the many different sectors within the Sri Lankan community. The High Commissioner, Mr Bill Tweddell, Dominic Trindade, Mr Titon Mitra and Mr Dunstan Fernando were extremely helpful in coordinating our visits into the exceedingly beautiful countryside, which which were very informative.

It is very difficult to select highlights, but I just want to briefly mention some highlights of the visit for me. One was the meeting with three Australian women who were doing volunteer work with NGOs. Mary Norwood, Sheila Francis and Sue Allen are engaged in very productive and helpful work in a very strife torn area of Sri Lanka. The visit to the prison, which I was privileged to make, was a very enlightening experience, and I am very grateful to Mr C.T. DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE 95TH INTER-PARLIAMENTARY CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 95th Inter‐Parliamentary Conference and to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 95th Inter‐Parliamentary Conference which was held in Istanbul between 15 and 20 April 1996. I might also point out to the Senate that, in order to pass on my recollections while they were fresh in my mind, I spoke on this matter in the adjournment debate on 1 May. As a consequence, I will spare you all from going over the same ground again. I managed to thank most of those involved during that speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I did, however, neglect to thank the hosts in Turkey. The Turkish government were extraordinarily generous in their treatment of the delegates to the conference. I came back with the same sort of feeling that many senators would have had: you hope that we could do at least as well in our country. The hospitality that was extended to us overseas really did us proud. It was certainly a great revelation to me just how well the Turkish people run their country and how extraordinarily hospitable they are.

The one thing I wanted to mention today, though, is the question of Cyprus. The IPU has a unique role in regard to Cyprus. I became involved mainly because of the work of a member in the other place, the member for Watson, the Hon. Leo McLeay. Mr McLeay has worked very hard and very long on the Cyprus committee of the IPU, and his contribution was such that the Australian delegation was asked if we could provide someone to carry on his work on that committee. We received a high degree of support and respect for the work which he had been able to do.

I was very happy to leap into the breach because we have a very strong Greek Cypriot community in Sydney, one which I have been associated with for more years than I care to remember. I was more than happy to try to deal with the very difficult issues which are based in Cyprus.

Cyprus is a very unhappy and a very unlucky country. Unfortunately, the IPU is the only international organisation which deals with both sides of the fence in Cyprus. The problem is very difficult for the United Nations, quite apart from the fact that it is embarrassing to have in the middle of Europe and the middle of the Mediterranean a country which is effectively partitioned. It is difficult also in that they can only recognise what they believe is the rightful government of Cyprus. But from the Turkish point of view, their argument is that, pursuant to the original agreement which made them co‐protectors of Cyprus, they certainly had nothing to do with Cyprus or its partitioning and they acted only in defence of the Turkish community there, which was one of their rights under the original agreement.

So what you have in Cyprus is a very unfortunate stalemate. For the people there living conditions really are intolerable. The whole thing has dragged on because no-one has been able to find a way out of this particular wood. As a consequence, their lives are made miserable because they cannot do things like attend a funeral on the other side of the border. There are all sorts of problems in terms of power, telephones and so on. All of this has been running on for some 30 years or more. It is a very sad and unhappy place.

The IPU does a great job in being able to talk to representatives from both sides in an informal way and try to work to some sort of lessening of the tensions, if not some ultimate resolution of the problems, they find on the island. One of the things that the IPU has been able to do is try to encourage cross‐border links—sporting links and other cultural links—between the two sides as a means of bringing down the tensions which so blight the life of the people on that particular island.

The IPU is also in an important position because, given the fact that it can talk to representatives from both sides, there was an extensive debate on the whole Cyprus question in the IPU on the final day. Again, that is not something that is easily done in other international forums such as the UN. I feel that the IPU is doing a good job there. I know it is difficult to maintain interest and it is very difficult to find willing members from other countries who want to go to a problem which has been around for so long and which does not necessarily hold out any great hope of resolution. Nevertheless, I trust that anybody from Australia will leap into the breach in future delegations and try to do their bit to find some way out of the problem.

There are many other things that I could talk about in terms of the report but we have several other members of the delegation in the other place, including the leader and deputy leader, and I am sure that they will all avail the parliament of their experiences and give a full account. Having already spoken on the matter, I will let my remarks finish there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Preamble, page 1 (line 8), omit "Most", substitute "Many".

Our amendment No. 1 is meant to reduce the complacency of one of the first sentences in the preamble. I am not sure what is the point of saying something like this in a bill—apart from making some sort of political statement—if it does not actually relate to reality. The bill says:

What do you mean by `appropriate'? I think the evidence suggests that many people pay really substantial portions of their income for housing. TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Margetts relating to the Housing Assistance Bill. I make the point that a majority of Australians are home owners. In fact, most are home owners. I think that the current wording of the bill is adequate and appropriate. As such, the opposition will not be supporting the amendment.
—I would like to add for the record that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Greens (WA) amendment No. 1 to the Housing Assistance Bill. We consider it slightly pedantic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply add that that is the view of the government as well in relation to amendment No. 2 of the Housing Assistance Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Preamble, page 1 (lines 8 to 9), omit "of an appropriate standard".

Our amendment No. 2 to the preamble to the Housing Assistance Bill says, `of an appropriate standard'. The phrase `housing of an appropriate standard' might lead people to believe that we have appropriate standards. In many places there are virtually no insulation standards, there are no guidelines to orienta tion, and there are no guidelines in terms of ventilation in tropical dwellings. We do have safety and engineering standards, but we have virtually no environmental standards.

Many of the houses in southern areas are very cold in winter. We have a lot of empty‐walled asbestos or single brick houses. We have houses with louvred windows where the weather may get to below freezing.

A few years ago, I heard a lecture by an expert in energy efficient design from near Manchester in England. He spoke of how design requirements for houses in England were nearly 100 years behind those in Sweden and other Scandinavian countries. He was outlining the difference that made on energy bills. Considering what the government has been saying about greenhouse gas, this is really quite interesting: as an aside, he said that, though the houses in England were less well designed to retain heat than in Denmark or Sweden, the coldest, most miserable winter he has ever had was in Brisbane, in Queensland. He put it down to the total failure to incorporate any idea of heat retention in house designs. This is typical of Australian housing.

In the south we see houses that make it almost impossible to retain heat. In the north we see poorly insulated, poorly ventilated houses put up in tracts. They may be framed houses with some thin sheathing on the outside, hardiplank, weatherboard, or whatever. So-called better houses may be made of bricks that have been hauled from the south and made to standard southern‐suburban design. There is often little incorporation of traditional design, even in areas like Broome, where traditional designs incorporating better ventilation appropriate to the tropics have been developed in the past.

It is not as if these factors have not been recognised. Almost all literature about what can be done about the greenhouse effect includes information urging people to insulate their houses. This mostly is suggested as something to be done by householders after they buy. But any survey of progressive policies notes that many nations or states elsewhere in the world include in building codes requirements for minimum insulation standards. Most have varying standards for roofs, for walls, even for windows. In the United States and northern Europe, many areas have minimum standards for the insulating quality of window glass. They require high insulation double glazing because, after insulating ceilings and walls, the windows are the areas where most heat enters or escapes.

If anyone does even a minimum perusal of environmentally sound design, they will find a plethora of other measures, often simple measures, for creating long-term benefits in terms of energy efficiency and the comfort of residents: making certain that eaves overhang for windows is appropriate to block the sun in summer and to let it in during the winter is a simple thing for during the design stage; and considering orientation of major windows to make certain that most of them do not face a problem with direction, like having it south in cold areas where such windows will never get sunlight. There is also the measure of using skylights, and so on. These are easy to do in the beginning; hard to fix or change afterwards. These sorts of considerations have been part of many government strategies and policies for greenhouse responses, for policies relating to ecologically sustainable development and elsewhere. The idea is not new to government. There have been programs to promote such building codes. There is the Amcord program within the department of housing. The better cities program recognises the need for such measures, but only slightly. In part, there is a recognition of the fact that it is much easier and much cheaper to build houses in an environmentally sound way than it is to try to retrofit. It is recognised that most people do not get to design their own houses. Even when buying new houses, it is usually a developer that determines the choices and options a buyer has.

It is important then to ensure that the new houses are built well from an environmental viewpoint. It is even more important where housing is not built with house purchase in mind, where the intention is for rental. Renters generally have less legal option to retrofit, even if they have the money.

It becomes an equity issue. Where poor people rent and have trouble affording heat and cooling, it can become a health problem. It is an environmental issue and an issue of family costs. It is also an issue of social costs, since failure of demand management on energy means that the state must build new power plants, put in newer and bigger powerlines and substations, increase gas purchase, build new gas lines and install new pumping stations. But I guess that the government would consider that as growth.

It is believed that the introduction of energy efficiency in buildings here, including commercial and industrial buildings, could reduce electricity and gas demand by over 15 per cent. It is something we could do about the greenhouse effect that would not cost business a thing. It would provide jobs and reduce state outlays and household and business overheads. We are not talking about freezing in the dark, which is what the present policy leads to. We are talking about being comfortable at low cost by designing buildings so we do not have to throw away energy, heat, coolness or money.

I repeat: effectively, there are almost no environmental or energy efficiency standards in Australian housing. There should be but it becomes ludicrous and negligent when government is actually in the position of building housing itself and does not even take action in its own projects. This has been the case with Commonwealth‐state housing, and it is not good enough to say that it is the state's fault.

The Commonwealth has a responsibility for the greenhouse response effort. The Commonwealth spends millions on promoting sound design. The Commonwealth provides the money for state housing and has a basic duty to ensure taxpayers' money is spent well. It has a duty to ensure that human rights and social welfare are considered. It has a duty to consider that the money it is spending on housing is not spent so badly that the Commonwealth must then pick up a large burden of costs through energy subsidies to poor people trying to get warm. It has a duty to ensure that its housing expenditure is not increasing its health expenditure. This may not be what economists who see a fragmented department by department bottom line mean by efficiency but it is what the Greens mean by both economic and social efficiency.

It is not efficient to have no standards when that increases economic and quality of life costs in other areas. This was finally recognised last year, at least in respect of government funded housing, when the government talked about new criteria for the CSHA, which would include environmental standards. We welcomed that move. We do not believe it is appropriate for the new government to cut that out. We know the new government is not necessarily friendly to any environmental measure but cutting out the environmental aspect of the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement really goes too far.

Many people can still afford housing; an increasing number cannot do so easily. Environmentally appropriate housing is almost non-existent. It is simply not correct to say that most people can obtain appropriate, affordable housing. It, therefore, should not be said. This is the background to these two amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting this second amendment that has been moved by Senator Margetts. I really do not believe omitting four words in the preamble of the Housing Assistance Bill 1996 is the way forward in terms of our addressing any inadequacies that Senator Margetts sees in the national greenhouse response strategy. Like her, I have always accepted the absolute importance for us to have an adequate and appropriate response on the greenhouse issue. For its part, the opposition has always acknowledged that it sees climate change as the most significant international environment issue that we face.

SPEECH.PARA: I do believe there are better ways of progressing this issue. I will certainly be listening carefully to the arguments that Senator Margetts puts forward in relation to her fourth amendment to insert the words `and ecologically appropriate' after the words `adequate' on page 2, line 6 of the preamble. Depending on the strength of your argument, Senator, I do see that as perhaps a more sensible way of your progressing some of the concerns you have outlined in your contribution, which I accept are important.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Preamble, page 2 (after line 5), insert:

PARA.TAB: Many people have difficulty obtaining housing that is environmentally appropriate. Adequate insulation and design to minimise water and energy consumption without compromising amenity is not generally required or provided. Urban planning often does not take the need to reduce mechanised transport or to optimise passive solar exposure into consideration.

People who are economically or socially disadvantaged may be less likely to obtain environmentally appropriate housing. This can have adverse economic effects. They may also have difficulty obtaining housing in areas that maximise their income through proximity to required services, adequate public transport, employment, shopping and areas for social interaction and support.

SPEECH.PARA: The first paragraph of our third amendment—and once again we are still on page 2 of the preamble—makes explicit the concerns the Commonwealth ought to have in regard to environmental design. I have gone into a number of issues in speaking to my previous amendments so I will not repeat myself fully, which you will be pleased to hear.

There is a huge range of design options that go well beyond insulation. There are things like underfloor heat sinks, integrated glasshouse areas, traum walls and a broad range of passive solar design measures that could be integrated into design, especially where it is designed for medium density state rental housing. The designs have been around for decades and are of proven worth. Many states actually have advisory services to promote such options. They just do not take their own advice.

There is also a range of active solar elements that could be included, the biggest being solar water heating. This should be standard in publicly owned housing wherever practical, which is almost everywhere in Australia.

Our amendment also includes water conservation. There are a number of design features that promote water conservation. There are low consumption shower heads and so on at one end and the more radical things such as designing grey water systems so they are easier to use for garden watering at the other. Water conservation is increasingly an issue in most urban areas. It is another area where there are Commonwealth and state policies to ensure water is conserved. We do live on a dry continent and there is no reason water waste should be built into public housing.

The last sentence of our first paragraph expands the issue of environmental design in housing to more explicitly include urban design, and I will speak briefly to this. The better cities program was specifically devised to address some of these concerns, and the concerns about urban design have appeared in things like greenhouse strategies and the ecologically sustainable development policy.

The basic idea is that when we design our cities, even more than designing our houses, we make decisions that will determine the day-to-day options we have available. These policies determine our range of choice. A technologist once said about choice that social choice is often made once, and made effectively for everyone. For example, once people choose cars as the major form of transport, the choice to use a horse for daily transport effectively disappears. It becomes impractical for most people.

In the structure of our cities, we persistently choose to live in a way highly dependent on the private motor vehicle. In part, this is based on past choice. We have suburbs and sprawling cities often with lower density than almost anywhere but Los Angeles. It is hard to do without cars so we tend to build for cars, but building for cars just makes us that more dependent.

The initial choices were not accidents. Many of you, particularly those with children, may have seen a movie a few years ago called Who Framed Roger Rabbit?. It was a cartoon set in Los Angeles in the 1940s. It was about a plot to buy up all the trams in that city, rip up the lines and build freeways. Not many people realised that this was a true story.

PARA.BREAK: In the 1930s, in Los Angeles and 44 other US cities, a consortium, composed of Stan dard Oil, General Motors, and Firestone tyres, at a time when Los Angeles had one of the best public transport systems in the world bought all the trams and ripped up the lines. Since then a lot of petrol cars and tyres have been sold and Los Angeles has become the global symbol of urban sprawl and smoggy mess. Recently, Los Angeles has embarked on a program to bring back the trams in the form of electric light rail. It is expected to cost billions but the city sees it as one of the only ways of starting to deal with its huge environmental problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently there has been a lot of attention on the environmental impact of car use in Sydney. In Perth, a few years ago, we had the first photochemical smog events, events which have now become regular. We may not have the tendency to inversion that plagues Los Angeles but we do have environmental problems in our cities as a consequence of car use.

Car dependency creates environmental problems. Cars consume a large amount of resources in their creation. New so‐called efficient cars usually gain efficiency by reduced use of materials, making them lighter and thinner and needing less energy to move them. This also makes them more fragile and less long‐lasting. This in turn increases throughput.

Today's cars are clapped‐out bombs after 10 or 15 years, while older cars are still in everyday use. New cars may need less material to make but we have to replace them more often. Over time, the material and energy used in fabrication is not less because the time between creation and disposal decreases. Car use entails a lot of emissions. Greenhouse gases are an obvious factor, as is lead in older cars. But there are many other emissions and pollutants.
