DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliament: Length of Term of Office

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the years, there have been many speeches in this chamber on the subject of the length of term of parliaments. In the lead‐up to the referendums put to the Australian people on 3 September 1988 the momentum actually increased. However, electors rejected a change in the constitution at that time. There were significant disadvantages in putting an option of a four‐year term to the people in that year. After all, it was our bicentennial year, when people were wanting to celebrate the advantages of our constitution and the great benefits that have come to our country because of the foresight of those people who drew it up. The mood was just not right for focussing on change at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: A more significant reason for its failure was the suspicion with which Australians looked upon this proposed change. And rightly so. The establishment of the Constitutional Commission was always suspect. Proposals for changing our constitution, the fundamental framework for governing, should be discussed by the people's representatives, not a commission whose members are selected by the government, whose terms of reference are imposed by the government and whose findings are pre-empted by the government. Australians are indeed intelligent people. They suspected that there was political advantage for the then Labor Party, and they were not wrong. So all the referendums at that time were lost.

The referendum on four-year terms was linked to changes in the Senate. It removed the fixed term of senators and established a system of permanent double dissolutions. As the Hon. Peter Reith pointed out at the time in the other House, it removed the one fixed element in the system. At the time, the Hon. Gareth Evans was reported in the Canberra Times to have said, `The way to abolish the Senate, or at least muzzle it, is to white ant it from within.' Australians were rightly suspicious of the intent of the referendum proposals and, therefore, rejected them.

While history does not favour the success of referendums—in that out of 38 amendments to the constitution put to referendum only eight have succeeded—when they have actually represented a genuine and honest attempt to improve the constitution for the benefit of all Australians, our people have actually been quite happy to support referendum change. Recognition of Aborigines as Australian citizens, for example, has never been an issue since that referendum was passed.

Now, eight years after the last referendums were put to the electorate, there is an increasing urgency to create a more stable economic environment. As our economic situation becomes increasingly complex, both nationally and also internationally, the certainty of a four-year term, particularly a fixed four-year term, would reduce the number of variables from which business would have to work. It would not only be our business leaders who would welcome a four-year fixed term; foreign companies, too, looking for investment opportunities would be keen to add the benefit of a four-year term of parliament to the other advantages that Australia has to offer.

Overseas investors find Australia attractive for many reasons, not least is the relative political stability. We are only one of a few countries which have never been devastated by a civil war or an invasion by a foreign power in the last 200 years. The benefits which our peaceful history has brought to overseas investments are well known. However, once these potential investors become aware that a new government has only three years to implement its policies, they find that they may need to reconsider their options. If that happens to come on a business scene halfway through a government term or later, they are confronted with the possibility of an election and change in policy at any time. Very few major decisions can be made by governments or businesses after the first 18 to 24 months following a federal election.

What is one of the few factors encouraging the Japanese, for example, to invest in Australian developments? Confidence—confidence that the rules on which investments are based will remain constant. This confidence can be further engendered by extending the term of parliament to four years. It will also mean that, once new measures are taken, business can be confident that the ground rules will stay the same for at least four years.

There have been more federal elections since 1949 in Australia than there have been in the US, which has fixed biennial terms. Four-year terms would bring the federal government into line with all state governments apart from Queensland. The vast majority of democratic countries have terms of at least four years. In fact, Britain and Canada and a number of others actually have terms of five years.

The cost of these elections is of grave concern to many people, who believe that there have been far too many over the years. The estimated cost of the federal election in March 1996 was $54 million. This figure does not include the estimated $33.4 million element of public funding. That is a total of $87.4 million of taxpayers' money. Yes, you have heard correctly. It was $87.4 million. Of course, that does not include all the other money that is privately spent on election campaigns.

This figure of $87.4 million compares with $39.8 million spent on the 1984 federal poll. The 1996 cost was more than double that of the 1984 federal poll, and that doubling between 1984 and 1996 can be largely explained by the introduction of public funding of election campaigns. But the message is clear. More elections mean more money—money that can be much more effectively used, I believe, elsewhere. The costs of polls have skyrocketed. Obvious savings would be gained with fewer elections; thus, it is quite an attractive proposition.

Many considerations have to be taken into account by a government when calling an election. Fewer elections would reduce the problem of trying to steer clear of state elections. You have the example of this last election, where the Tasmanian election was held the week before the federal poll, making it extremely difficult for federal candidates to get across their message in just one week. Of course, there are a lot more state parliamentarians than there are federal parliamentarians.

While it is known that a state election cannot be held on the same day as a federal election, since a federal election does take precedence, the Tasmanian government had to call its election not knowing what the federal government was going to do. In those circumstances, the inevitable scenario eventuated where the Tasmanian poll was just one week ahead of the federal poll. You can just imagine the competition for space for advertising in the three regional newspapers in Tasmania. Fewer elections would at least reduce the possibility of this sort of event occurring again.

In a slightly different scenario, the Victorian state election was called just one week after the federal election. The pressure this put on the electoral officers is something that would more likely be avoided if the federal House of Representatives had a four-year fixed term. States would have clear guidelines to go by in their choice of election date, and this would again provide greater certainty for business.
I refer to a paper in the Business Council Bulletin No. 30 of January 1987, which reports:

. . . the frequency of elections is not simply a nuisance or irritation; it clearly has major implications for government decision-making, for budgetary policies and therefore for the economic climate in which businesses have to make major investment decisions.

It goes on to say that one of the consequences of shorter terms is a curtailed budgetary cycle, and this in turn disrupts a government's economic strategy. The paper refers to the adverse effect elections have on retail sales. I am sure that my colleagues here are aware of the pressures from the retail sector on a government not to hold an election in the lead-up to Christmas because of the very likely impact on revenue, lost revenue, during the most profitable time of the year. These sorts of arguments, I believe, strongly support the case for four-year fixed terms for the federal government. I urge all senators to give the issue serious consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the department have guidelines or protocols concerning the provision of legal aid to serving military personnel in civil legal proceedings; if so, what are the financial obligations of the department with regard to the payment of the legal costs of members of the defence forces in civil legal proceedings resulting from the member's activities while off duty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Defence does have published guidance concerning the provision of legal aid to members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) in civil legal proceedings.

Where civil legal proceedings are brought against a member of the ADF in circumstances arising from his or her employment, the member (like any other Commonwealth employee) may apply to have defence of the action undertaken at Commonwealth expense. The procedures are set out in Section 21 of the Finance Directions, in force under the Finance Regulations.

In addition, a limited range of legal assistance with respect to civil legal proceedings is available to members in accordance with Defence Instruction (General) Personnel 12‐1 (General Scope of Legal Assistance Provided to Service Personnel and Legal Aid to ADF Members Overseas). (For members of the Army, this instruction is amplified by Defence Instruction (Army) Personnel 111‐2 (Legal Aid)). Copies of these instructions and Section 21 of the Finance Directions have been provided to Senator Woodley.

Under the Defence Instruction (General), an ADF legal officer may advise a member on the merits of any civil case and assist with preliminary documentation, such as the preparation of affidavits. The legal officer may not act for or formally represent the member in any civil action in the legal officer's military capacity but may, if a member of the Reserve Forces, be retained by the member as a private legal practitioner. Any legal fees charged by a Reserve legal officer consulted or retained by a member in a private capacity are payable by the member.

Where a member serving overseas faces litigation for civil damages in respect of an off‐duty incident, the member may make application for legal aid to the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services in the Attorney‐General's Department. The member will be required to contribute to the cost of legal aid provided, the contribution being calculated on the basis of the member's readily available cash reserves.

The financial obligations of the Commonwealth with regard to the payment of the legal costs of a member of the ADF in civil legal proceedings resulting from the member's activities while off‐duty are:
(a) within Australia the Commonwealth has no obligation to pay the member's private legal costs in such a case;
(b) overseas the Commonwealth will pay the member's legal costs, subject to a contribution from the member.
